PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, will be absent from Question Time today on Government business and questions normally directed to Mr Kerin should be directed to the Minister for Resources, Mr Peter Morris.

—I ask the Prime Minister: How will the continuing dramatic fall on the Australian stock market and this morning's increasing pressure on the Australian dollar affect investment, employment, interest rates and Budget projections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the National Party of Australia for his question. The first thing I would wish to say is that I believe it is appropriate that in this situation of a significant decline in prices on the Australian share market we are now experiencing, there not be panic on the part of the Government or at official levels. In that sense I welcome the statements that have been made in my absence by my colleague the Treasurer. I would suggest to the right honourable gentleman that the calls that some people, including himself, have made for a mini-Budget this year are not an appropriate reaction.

ANSWER.PARA: I say directly to the right honourable gentleman that of course it is not possible to say with precision or dogmatism what the effect of these falls will be in the areas of investment and employment to which he referred. But, insofar as the Budget outcomes are concerned, I simply say that I support what my colleague the Treasurer said, that on balance we think that the Budget outcomes should be substantially unaffected.

Insofar as the most recent indications are concerned, although of course the figure for the September quarter of the consumer price index (CPI) to which I refer was in its formulation before these events occurred, I simply say that the Budget forecast of an outcome of about a 6 per cent CPI increase by the end of 1987-88 seems to be on course. However, I say to the right honourable gentleman that the Government will be closely monitoring developments here and overseas. The right honourable gentleman can rest assured that the Government will take those courses of action which are necessary insofar as the Australian economy is concerned.

I remind him, of course-although I think he needs no reminding-that what is happening in the Australian markets is not something which is a reflection upon the Australian economy but which is part of a world-wide phenomenon. Indeed, I conclude by saying that in the discussions I have been able to have in my recent visit overseas I have been met universally with approbation for the economic policies followed by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the House of Australia's most recent initiatives to promote the World Health Organisation's global strategies to halt the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hawker for her question. Probably all members of the House recognise that Australia has received international recognition for its humane and comprehensive approach to the problem of AIDS. We have sought to share that knowledge with other nations and to play a role in developing an international strategy to combat the disease, with the result that Australia has taken a series of international initiatives this year. In May Australia took the initiative at the World Health Assembly with a resolution on AIDS. In July Australia, with the World Health Organisation, hosted a conference of Ministers from the Pacific region and the West Asian region to work out ways of encouraging co-operation in dealing with AIDS in this region of the world. The culmination of these activities came early today, Australian time, when the United Nations General Assembly passed an Australian-sponsored resolution on AIDS which is designed to promote international co-operation and co-ordination in the global fight against the disease. This resolution affirmed the importance of international co-operation in combating AIDS under the leadership of the World Health Organisation and the need to develop national strategies in an international context.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the significance of the issue and the gravity with which the United Nations General Assembly took it was that it interrupted the formal debate to be briefed by both the Director-General of the World Health Organisation, Dr Halfdan Mahler, and the head of the special program on AIDS, Dr Jonathan Mann. The resolution was proposed by Australia's Ambassador to the United Nations, Mr Richard Woolcott, and it received unanimous support. The decision to sponsor the resolution by Australia was in recognition of the role we had played in formulating and implementing strategies to prevent the spread of AIDS.

As the United Nations General Assembly recognised, AIDS is not just a public health problem. As we have seen in this country, AIDS has wide-ranging ramifications-economic and social-for areas other than health, such as employment, education, tourism and immigration. International co-operation in this area is of great practical importance in halting the spread of the disease. International co-operation is a precondition for the exchange of information on preventative measures, research and treatment. The movement of peoples and the movement of blood products are also important factors in the spread of disease. I think the consideration of this issue in the United Nations highest council attests to its global significance and accords the fight against AIDS its proper international recognition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that his Government's scheme to supplement 66 per cent of the salaries to the six Australian doctors in Fiji is to be terminated on 19 January 1988? As this will severely threaten the continuation of the medical school of the University of the South Pacific in Fiji and result in the withdrawal of the only orthopaedic surgeon in Fiji and the South Pacific and the cut-off of all specialised surgery in Fiji, how does this action reconcile with his own statements before his departure from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and the Foreign Minister's statement of 16 October on behalf of his Government in which he pledged to maintain Australia's traditional friendly relations with the people of Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the details to which the right honourable gentleman refers. I will undertake to make myself acquainted with them and the implications of what he has suggested, if it is accurate, will be examined. But as to the general question of Fiji and the attitude of my Government towards it, let me take this opportunity of stating the position briefly and, I hope, to the satisfaction of the House generally.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable members will appreciate, this is a matter that was the subject of discussion with my fellow heads of government of the Commonwealth in Vancouver. I am pleased to say to the House-I think all members will appreciate the fact-that there was a unanimity of view amongst the heads of government represented there, firstly, in regret at what had happened in Fiji and, secondly, that they should accept the proposal that I put. That was that the good offices of the Commonwealth should be made available so that, if those in authority in Fiji were willing, there could be an attempt from within the Commonwealth to provide some sort of mechanism whereby there could be consultation which would produce a result within Fiji both in terms of protecting the interests of all groups and people there and, following from that, in creating a situation in which an application by Fiji for renewed membership of the Commonwealth could be acceptable.

My Government played a leading role in those discussions, and it is our wish that there shall emerge in Fiji a position of the sort that I have just referred to, where the interests of all groups will be properly protected and there can be, as soon as possible, a return to the processes of parliamentary democracy. It is to assist in achieving those objectives that the policies of this Government are directed. I note with approval that the Foreign Minister has indicated in my absence, as I indicated in Vancouver, that the use of industrial action at this stage by the Australian trade unions is not helpful, we believe, in attempting to achieve the sort of outcome that we think is appropriate. Going back to the particulars of the question asked by the right honourable gentleman, I am not aware of them. I will have a look at the issue to see whether, in the particular circumstances, and if what he said is correct, there needs to be any review of that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask him to assure the House that the rumour that he is proposing to build a monorail from Ayers Rock to the Olgas is just a sick joke, or part of his quirky sense of humour, like the piddling, scratching, flea-bitten koalas. I ask the Minister whether he is seriously contemplating such an action which would, in the view of most people in Australia, completely ruin the aesthetics of Uluru National Park, which is part of the world heritage area. If he does go ahead, will he add to it a water slide on Ayers Rock and a McDonald's on top of the Olgas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer that rather cynical question as gently as I can. It is a matter of fact that the road from Ayers Rock to the Olgas is one of the more important tourism roads in Australia, inasmuch as it links two of the great attractions of Uluru National Park and that unique wilderness area of Australia. It is also a fact that that road is built on shifting sand dunes.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Opposition might find this very humorous, but they would not find it very humorous if they had heard the fears that have been registered by all sections of the tourism industry in the Northern Territory that if something drastic is not done about the road, people will be killed using it. They might think seriously about this. There are presently bans on the use of that road by every tourism operator in the Northern Territory simply because of the dangers involved in driving along it. It is a common daily occurrence for buses to be bogged on that road, for cars to turn over on that road and for the tourism industry in the Territory generally to treat it with the disrespect that it deserves.
—Build a tunnel.
—The attitude of Opposition members towards this question is typical of the attitude that they displayed to tourism in their seven years of non-government of this country--
—What about your own back bench?
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting.

—When they could do nothing about achieving the results that we have achieved since we have been in government. The only contribution of the honourable member for Flinders to tourism in Australia was to be part of the destruction of the habitat of the fairy penguin on Phillip Island when he was a land developer. So he is in a very poor position to be commenting. The need to have a reasonable form of communication and transportation between Ayers Rock and the Olgas I treat very seriously. Obviously for anybody to promote the dusty road that at present exists, which is a blight on the rather pleasant and very fragile environment of Uluru National Park is a nonsense. In the wet, which is the better time to view the Olgas, the road is impassable; in the summer, because it passes through sand dunes, it is a very dangerous piece of road. The Aboriginal traditional owners of Uluru will not allow a road to be directed through better territory so we are faced with the problem of constantly regrading what is almost an impossible piece of territory.

ANSWER.PARA: Propositions have been floated, some of which I support and some of which I do not, which require urgent investigation. One of those is the provision of a monorail. Of course, with the misguided conceptions and the prejudices that most people have with that word all of the fears that have been expressed by the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment have surfaced. I think it is important that people have access to the Olgas, particularly in the wet when the waterfalls are running on the Olgas and when the area is at its most pleasant. I do not want the Olgas to become the preserve in the wet simply of those people who can afford to charter an aeroplane or a helicopter to view them. The matter of a low level monorail-that is, one built about two or three feet above the ground so that it can be used in the wet-has been canvassed by the National Parks and Wildlife Service, which the former Minister administered. He knows that the Service supports it. It has achieved a notable amount of support from the Aboriginal communities which have control of Uluru National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong.

—I am not wrong at all. If the honourable member thinks I am wrong he should check it out with the senator for the Northern Territory, Senator Bob Collins, who has discussed the matter with them. They are very supportive of the idea simply because it will stop all those lunatics with four-wheel drives who now take off on that road, head off into the environment and destroy most of the beauty of that area, which is very sacred to the Aborigines who view the Olgas as being much more religiously important to them than Ayers Rock. What I have proposed is a convenient way of transporting people safely from the rock to the Olgas, which will allow the Territory to be traversed in the wet, which will eliminate the dangers which now face anybody who travels along that road, whether it be in a four-wheel drive, an ordinary motor car or a bus. It will in no way present the damage to the environment that is now presented by the dirty, dusty road that is there, which is dusty in the dry and muddy in the wet. It will enable access to the Olgas for all people no matter what their social or economic background.

ANSWER.PARA: If the proposal as has been put to me by the National Parks and Wildlife Service does go ahead, it will be the subject of an environmental impact study. It will be the subject of discussion with the Aboriginal traditional owners of Uluru National Park and would not be built without all those considerations being taken into account. But for anybody to suggest, as the former Minister has suggested today, that it should be accompanied by a waterslide on the rock or a razzle-dazzle or a big dipper or anything else is quite ridiculous and I find it rather repugnant that a man who had responsibility in this area should be casting such silly aspersions upon a very responsible attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the substantial level of net borrowing of financial enterprises from 1984-85 to 1987-87 as outlined in chart 12, page 33 of the Budget Papers. I ask the Treasurer why some financial enterprises, in particular State government insurance offices, have been permitted to become substantial net borrowers in recent years. What measures are being taken by State governments to reduce the net borrowing of the respective insurance offices in order to place these organisations on a sound financial basis?

—I am not aware of the statistics raised by the shadow Treasurer, but I will have a look at the implications of his question. The only thing I say in reply to the question is that there is supervision of the insurance industry and there is a supervisory commissioner in the Commonwealth area. Generally, the commissioner looks at the prudential arrangements of superannuation funds; but I am not aware, without advice, whether the commission looks at State funds. —Can the Minister for Resources advise the House of progress in the development of the export of livestock by air freight and the involvement of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in the expansion of this trade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and recognise his strong interest in this growing area of export activity. The Government has recently been involved in several innovative exports of livestock to what are, in effect, non-traditional markets, as part of the Government's determination to broaden our export base and export income. In particular, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has assisted in negotiating changes to the import procedures of receiving countries. The honourable member will recognise that on 17 September we shipped some 74 angora goats from South Australia to France, of all places, by regular scheduled air freight service, and another shipment of 150 goats left last week.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, on 24 September a consignment of 52 young camels left Alice Springs for the United States of America on a special DC8 charter flight.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a camel train instead of a monorail?

—These camels-I say for the benefit of the honourable member for Richmond-underwent a special three-month domestication and preparation period which included health tests to meet United States import requirements, and we anticipate further exports in 1988. Last month saw the first export of live pigs to Peru, when 1,501 pigs were transported by a special Boeing 747 charter flight. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service negotiated amendments to the Peruvian Government's import quarantine conditions to allow that shipment to proceed. In conclusion, I advise the honourable member that all 1,501 pigs arrived on that charter flight to Peru in good health and without any evidence of jet lag. We will continue to pursue these new market opportunities as they arise.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to my question to him yesterday when I referred him to his statement in which, in part, he said that the Government could raise more than $700m a year from death duties and that not taxing deceased estates is inequitable. I ask the Minister whether he recalls saying in his answer to me: `I do not know the source of the statement that was attributed to me', and, in response to an interjection which asked, `Did you say it or not?', saying, `As far as I know I did not'. Did the Minister make the remarks that I have attributed to him in a prepared speech at the Labor Day dinner at Clayton on 12 March 1984 and, if so, why did he yesterday mislead the Parliament; or does he just have a bad memory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think one of the remarkable characteristics of the Opposition is its great sense of history. Quite clearly, it is not learning, if I might say so, from the history of the Australian Labor Party which is that when one is in opposition, one spends one's time working solidly in terms of developing policy; one encourages debate; and when there are differences of view, one focuses on policy questions rather than on questions of personality.

ANSWER.PARA: I take it from the honourable member's question that, as usual, the Opposition is relying on some recent newspaper report. It appears that the honourable member was in fact referring to a speech that I may have made in 1984. As I suggested yesterday in answer to the honourable member's question, I have never resiled from the view and never ceased to argue in terms of the Government party room that we should be seeking a fairer taxation system. I accept-if this is what is implied in the honourable member's question-that I have consistently argued on the record from time to time in relation to various forms of capital taxation. It is certainly true that I supported this. Indeed, in a speech which I made to a recent private meeting, I pointed to the great success in terms of this Government's record in relation to taxation reform.

One of the reasons that certainly I am not going to indulge in personalities with respect to the front bench is that I am proud to be a member of a front bench which has carried through the first period of significant reform not only in terms of opposition parties but in terms of my own Party. In our period of government, unlike the Whitlam Government, we were prepared to take on the issue of taxation reform. We have taken that issue on and, indeed, the Treasurer has recently referred to the fact that he believes there is further work to do in the area of business taxation. When the Opposition is able to get itself together for long enough to have a serious debate on any policy question, but centrally on the question of taxation, it can refer to history. My understanding of the Opposition is that it is history and is likely to remain history for a very long time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to table a speech by the Hon. Brian Howe, Minister for Defence Support, dated 12 March 1984, with respect to that matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security seen a report in today's Age newspaper that the Council for the Single Mother and her Child is critical of the Government's new child support scheme because it will leave some supporting parents worse off? Can the Minister inform the House how the new scheme will work to help single parents and their children?
—Another one you got wrong, Brian.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might say so, the honourable member for Richmond is a fairly typical example of a member of the Opposition who always indulges in personality and rarely refers to a policy position. The total income of sole parents affected by the new income test on child support will be protected. The income that people receive by way of maintenance will not affect the pension so that it falls below the level of income that they were receiving on Budget day. Today's Age referred to the case of a sole parent with one child, who currently gets $25 a week in maintenance. The Age reports her fears that she will be worse off. We say that those fears are misplaced. A sole parent in her position now gets $166.15 a week. Under the separate income test, she will get $169.10. I believe that sole parents are being frightened without cause. We need to make it clear what the child support scheme is about.

ANSWER.PARA: We live in a society that cares more about collecting parking fines than it does about collecting child support or maintenance. Seventy per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay regular maintenance. This adds to poverty and burdens the social security system. The proportion of sole parents on social security has increased from 65 per cent to 85 per cent over the last decade. Superficially, the separate income test for child support may look tough, but if one looks at the total story for sole parents one sees that we have a commitment to full indexation of pensions; we are, of course, introducing the family assistance package; and we are providing major increases in income support for children in all low income families. It is fair and equitable that major benefits go to children who do not get adequate private support.

The child support scheme will deliver major benefits to children who do not get the maintenance to which they are entitled. Tomorrow my colleague the Attorney-General will introduce amendments to the Family Law Act and those amendments will lead to more adequate maintenance. We will establish the Child Support Agency in the Australian Taxation Office-that in itself, is something of a tax reform-to make sure that children get the maintenance to which they are entitled, when they need it; every month, regularly. The child support scheme is a major reform. It means that, for the first time, the children of separated parents can be assured of getting fairer and more adequate support.

The Age also reported that property settlements in the family law system will be income tested by the Department of Social Security. That is not true. Unfortunately, sole parent groups are spreading what I believe is a false alarm. Social Security will not be income testing property settlements. Rather, the Family Law Act will be amended to require the courts to specify in orders whether maintenance is provided in a capital form. It is not fair to apply an income test to a pensioner who receives regular cash in maintenance and not apply the test to a pensioner who gets property in lieu of maintenance. Settlements which are identified by the courts as being part of the maintenance settlement, and not property settlement, will be income tested.

This Government continues to support the poorest children in our community. The child support scheme simply calls for an equitable share of the cost of support for children between the Government and separated parents. In terms of the Government's commitment to the elimination of child poverty, let me make it quite clear that the child support scheme is an essential component of our overall approach to that extraordinarily important objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to the decision taken by the Senate to refer to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade the record wastage rates from the Australian Defence Force and their effect on our defence capabilities. As the Government has belatedly acknowledged the magnitude of the problem generated by these record wastage rates, will the Minister assure the Parliament that the Joint Committee will have full access to any defence personnel it may wish to call before the Committee, including the chiefs of the Services who have been warning the Government for some time that the Services cannot sustain this wastage? Does the Minister still hold the view that this wastage of personnel from the Services is good for morale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McPherson for his question. The first part of the question related to the Parliamentary Committee. I have seen the terms of reference from the Senate. I will be discussing that reference with Minister Beazley when he returns from his trip to the South Pacific and New Guinea early next week. I can provide more details on that question next week. On the whole issue of separations which, I note, is coming up for discussion later today--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Resignations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite refer to resignations. When I talk about separations, I am not just talking about resignations. When people leave the Services, they leave for a number of reasons. I include in all the details about separations a magnitude of reasons. Many of them are leaving because they have served 20 years which means that they can receive a pension. After 20 years of very valuable service to this country they choose to leave, but they have provided a service. Included in the reasons for that separation figure is ill health. People may enter the Services on short term appointments and leave again. There is a lot of misunderstanding about these figures. That has been fuelled by the Opposition, particularly by the honourable member for McPherson. I am very pleased that this afternoon we will have a sensible debate about this mater. I have never said that high separation rates are good for morale. What I have said is that over the last 10 years the average separation rate has been about 11.1 per cent per annum. Currently the rate is 12.6 per cent. I have acknowledged that there are problems about that, particularly in the area of pilots. I am addressing those problems.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the recently concluded Montreal protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer, what action is the Government taking to control chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I acknowledge that he is the leader of environmental protection in the rather sensitive area in which Dunkley is situated. Last month Australia became a party to the Vienna Convention on the Earth's Ozone Layer. The Convention provides the framework for international action to protect the ozone shield. A protocol to the Convention was finalised in Montreal on 16 September, which will lead to steps by countries to control emissions of chemicals known to damage the ozone layer. The Government supports the protocol and will give early consideration to Australia becoming a signatory to it. In the process, there will be consultation with State governments and, of course, every other interested party.

ANSWER.PARA: As a party to the protocol, Australia would be required to put in place controls on chlorofluorocarbons, which will initially freeze their consumption in 1989 to 1986 levels. The Government will address the form of legislation needed to implement the provisions of the Montreal protocol. The Australian Democrats were quoted recently as intending to pursue legislation banning the use of CFCs in aerosol cans and promoting recycling of these chemicals. This proposal may not be sufficiently comprehensive to fulfil obligations derived from the Montreal protocol. However, the Government hopes that all parties in this place, including the Liberal Party of Australia, which, as I understand it, has a new-found-or a first-found-interest in environmental protection, will support the proposed legislation to implement controls on ozone depleting substances when we introduce it very shortly. The need for action on this issue is given added momentum because of the report in recent days that the most recent measurements by scientists show a significant deepening of the ozone hole over Antarctica.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I refer the Minister to recent remarks by Australia's foremost Army field commander, General Jeffery, that because of manpower shortages, the 1st Division could sustain operations for only four to six weeks-a view I confirm following my visit to the Division last week. Why has the Government sought to downgrade and discredit these remarks by General Jeffery? Why is the Government again ignoring professional advice based, as it is, on an exercise which is costing this country millions of dollars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like the member for McPherson, also looked at the military exercise known as Diamond Dollar. I must say that I came away with a different focus from that of the honourable member for McPherson. I would like to put the comments of General Jeffery in perspective. General Jeffery has said that the Australian took his comments out of context. The honourable member for McPherson may enjoy reading the text of his letter to the editor of the Australian last week. I would like to take this opportunity to comment on the Diamond Dollar exercise and on the points General Jeffery raised. The current strategic situation does not require the whole of the 1st Division to be at a high level of operational readiness for rapid deployment. The 3rd Brigade, based at Townsville, and part of the Operational Deployment Force, is at full strength. It can be deployed quickly and sustained for at least six months and probably indefinitely on low level operations. That is a fact that has been reinforced by the Chief of the Defence Force. Only very high priority units of the 1st Division are manned to their full war establishment in peace. The Division is structured to receive the additional 3,000 personnel required in a crisis and the round out of regular Army units with Army reserves partly addresses this requirement. Every good commander, of course, would like more resources and manpower. But current balance between expenditure on personnel operating costs and capital investments is about right in our present strategic situation.

ANSWER.PARA: Exercise Diamond Dollar is mainly an Army exercise. It is a little unrealistic when we take into account the overall resources available to meet any threat to this country. The 1987 Defence White Paper emphasised increased northern training. Exercise Diamond Dollar is by no means our first exercise in the far north-in fact, it is the second I have been to in the far north-but it is the biggest for many years. It is not surprising that lessons are to be learnt or relearnt from an exercise such as this, especially in regard to mobility and logistic support.

I take this opportunity to say something positive about this exercise because I get sick to death of the Opposition whingeing and whining about defence when there are so many positive things going on in this area. One of them was Exercise Diamond Dollar. The Diamond Dollar exercise was carried out by Australian troops with the assistance of the Americans. We had some 7,000 troops involved in this military exercise. We had 2,000 vehicles and 44 aircraft deployed in far north Queensland, in the Gulf of Carpentaria. Can honourable members imagine the logistic support systems that are required to support the troops in such an exercise? There is hardly any civil infrastructure up there. There was a full battalion parachute jump with equipment conducted by a Sydney-based unit. We also had the opportunity to see our Black Hawk helicopters in operation which were on loan from America. We were able to see the effectiveness that the helicopters will have when we actually acquire them-again, on an initiative of this Government.

One of the greatest successes of this exercise has been to see the total integration of the Reserve Force and the regulars. As one walked around this exercise-or, as I had to do, fly in in a chopper-one could see a total integrated force; the regulars and the reserves. As the Minister responsible for this portfolio, I was very proud to see our men and women up there working together. There are lessons to be learnt from this exercise. That is one of the reasons such exercises are held. They have proved to be very successful. I also take this opportunity to compliment the men and women who made this exercise so successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs noted recent reports that consideration is being given to abolishing the requirement for visas for Japanese tourists coming to Australia? Could he give the Government's position on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kingston for his question. It is true that again the question of visa entry into Australia was raised by me with members of the Japanese tourist industry on my recent visit to that country. The matter has been raised by our own domestic tourist agencies over a period of years. This Government has maintained the position of previous governments, that is, favouring the retention of the integrity of our visa entry system for all purposes. It is true that some governments around the world-our near neighbours, New Zealand, and Japan and others-have initiated visa-free entry. It has brought with it certain troubles but they try to weigh up the benefits against the disadvantages. Nevertheless, Australia has maintained a very strict adherence to the visa entry system. We have been loath to entertain breaking that system down, because it has been felt by the previous Government and by this Government that demand would grow once we started to do this.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, because of the explosion in tourism to Australia and the importance now of the industry due to the enormous success of my colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, it has been necessary for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to become cognisant of the role it plays in seeing that we do not act as any sort of a barrier to the continued growth of tourism in this country. To that extent, the Government has put in additional resources, manpower, throughout the major areas-Japan, North America, and Western Europe-to make sure that there is no great delay in the issuing of visas to people wishing to visit this country. Now in Japan, for instance, the turnaround can in some cases, across the counter, be 24 hours and in most cases it is certainly no longer than 48 hours.

No evidence has been presented to this Government that visas in any way hinder the number of people who wish to visit this country. Nevertheless, as the question was raised with me in Japan, as the industry is so enormously important, as we all acknowledge that the Japanese tourist is a very good tourist-there is very little incidence of overstaying the period for which a visa is issued-and as we are likely to see the numbers grow astronomically over the next decade, the view I expressed to the Japanese, and which I now express to the House, is that as far as I am concerned all cards are on the table. We will continue to review all the systems that are necessary because we are not going to do anything at all that would hinder the growth of this vitally important industry.

In terms of the necessity for the issuing of visas, we are experimenting to the extent that we can. Last week Qantas Airways Ltd announced that it was going to fly into Nagoya. We have now given Qantas the opportunity of being the agency to receive applications for visas in Nagoya, which should hurry up the process in that part of Japan. But we have been reluctant, and have refused in the past, to shift away from what has been a long term policy of this country and to water down the visa necessity which has been maintained for anybody wishing to enter this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct an allied question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Does the Minister still believe that more than two million international visitors will come to Australia in 1988? Does he concede that, if this is so, there are not enough airline seats available into Australia to handle the numbers? In light of the fact that it is almost impossible now to get seats out of Europe, Asia, Japan and the United States of America for tourists, will the Minister pledge to kick a few heads in Qantas Airways Ltd, in the Department of Transport and Communications and even among his ministerial colleagues to ensure that there are enough services operating into Australia to handle the expected increase in the number of international visitors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable members uses a strange analogy-kicking heads to put bums on seats. Yesterday I had some discussions with my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications. As a result of those discussions, an urgent conference is being called between his Department, my Department and the Australian Tourist Commission to try to find a way to cope with this problem of our not having enough plane seats or, conversely, of `too many people' wanting to come to Australia. Mind you, it is a problem that 157 or so countries around the world would like to have. None of them have it but us, so I suppose that it is a good problem to be faced with. Nevertheless, it is an urgent problem.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has assured me that Qantas will be flying something like 16 supplementary flights a week-I think that was the number given to me-in the peak period. We have made available the opportunity for people to take charter flights into Australia to cope with the increasing numbers. Every effort will be made to see that not one passenger intending to come to Australia will be disappointed. I have been quoted in the Press today as saying that it would be an incredible difficulty for Qantas to cope with our pro- jected number of something like five million visitors by the year 2000. If Qantas were to maintain its half share of the market that would mean that it would bring 2 1/2 million visitors a year. On average, that is 50,000 a week. Of course, in some weeks, in the peak period, that would be 80,000 passengers a week.

In order for Qantas to maintain that half of the market it would need an enormous injection of funds, with Jumbo jets being worth $250m, not the $50m reported in the Press. Obviously, it would require an enormous growth to be able to cope with that 50 per cent of the market. That is a problem the Government will need to address urgently. I do not think any honourable member would want us to give away very easily Qantas's rights, under international agreements, to half of the market. For instance, there is a great reluctance in the United States to allow Qantas the right to fly to New York, which it has long sought. We see a demand by United States carriers for Qantas to give away a lot of its rights but, on the other end, no recognition that reciprocal rights should be granted to Qantas. As I am sure the honourable member for Fadden knows, the same thing was happening with Japan. Qantas sought for a long time four extra flights into Japan. Japan Air Lines was not in a position to take up the corresponding four flights, so permission was withheld for a long time. Eventually All Nippon Airways Co. Ltd accepted the right to two flights a week, Qantas got its four and Japan Air Lines got the other two. Maybe that has solved, at least partly, the problem in regard to Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good argument for abandoning the agreement.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Hawke Government's continuing neglect of the Australian Defence Force as evidenced by the record high wastage rates from the Australian Defence Force and the reduction in the operational capabilities of the Australian Defence Force.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is being brought forward to condemn the Government for its neglect of Australia's Defence Force and the men and women who man it. The Government is failing in its first duty, and that is to provide adequate security for Australia, Australians, and Australian territory. It is presiding over the decline of one of the most professional defence forces in the work, not through active government policies but by sheer neglect. We bring this matter of public importance forward at this time of economic difficulty because it demonstrates our concern about what is happening to the defence forces of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has allowed the service men and women of this country to become second-class citizens in their own land. For four years, the defence personnel have looked to the Government for assistance, but looked in vain. They have now decided that it is nothing but froth and bubble as far as promises to the defence forces are concerned, and they are voting with their feet. The first Minister for Defence in the first Hawke Government tried hard, but he simply did not understand what defence was all about or what made defence personnel tick. The second and present Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has a grand academic plan for the defence of this country which takes no account of the personnel who are manning the defence forces. He treats them as cogs in a machine and as nine to five public servants, without any understanding of what they are trying to do. It looks as though he is about to bail out of this position because the long haul is far too tough, so he has passed the buck to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), and she has, in some way, passed it to Ms Mayer, to whom we have already referred in the House.
The Minister's contribution, despite what she has said, as reported in the Melbourne Sun, is that high wastage rates are good for morale.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said.

—The Minister can get up and deny it in a minute. Last night, on Channel 7, she said that she was working on morale in the defence forces, as though it were a piece of putty or something made of wood or a tap that can be turned off and on. Her theory about increasing morale in the defence forces will push the wastage rates up even higher. The Defence Force of this country is bleeding to death. It is crying out for help, and not only will the Government not stop the bleeding, but it will not even provide the bandages.

SPEECH.PARA: As most people know, the present position is as follows. In the last four years, 32,000 service men and women have resigned from the Defence Force. That is more than half the trained personnel in the defence forces of this country. In the four years to June next year, the predictions are that 36,000 will have gone. The resignation rate has gone from 6,700 in 1983-84 to 9,000 in 1986-87, and in 1987-88 we expect to see an annual loss of something between 10,000 and 11,000. Officer resignations have gone from 5.4 per cent to over 12 per cent. We have lost 250 pilots in the last two years. The replacement rate for pilots in the training system is about 130 over two years. We have lost 75 pilots in the last three months. If that is projected over 12 months, we shall lose 300 in the coming year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did they go?

—Do not give us that old Qantas stuff. The 20-year average loss has been 47 in a year. In a recent survey, 88 per cent of Navy personnel condemned the Government. The Commander 1st Division, General Jeffery, said last week that the 1st Division could sustain itself in the field for something like four to six weeks, and the Government's reaction is to stop publishing figures. What a stupid, pathetic and futile act.

SPEECH.PARA: The causes of the resignation rate are quite clear and, for God's sake, the last thing that we want is yet another investigation. Generally speaking, they are government disinterest and the fact that the people in the defence forces are quite aware that the Minister has no interest in them as people. In 27 pages of a defence document brought down in this Parliament two weeks ago there was one paragraph relating to personnel and that was so obscure as to be meaningless. The Hamilton report, Supporting Service Families, which the Government keeps on talking about, made 15 major recommendations, not one of which has been implemented-only one has been partially implemented. The Minister for Defence says that service personnel did not join for an easy life. What a stupid, fatuous, patronising remark. His ministerial ambitions are all he considers in being responsible for the defence portfolio and the sooner he moves on the better because the men and women who are manning our defence services have lost faith. The White Paper is falling around his ears because of lack of funding. For God's sake, if he cannot make a go of it he should move aside and hand the portfolio over to someone who can make a go of it. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, I believe, is full of good intentions but she will need more than good intentions to pull this situation out of the fire.

Some of the matters that need particular attention are pay and overtime. Every time there is a claim before the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal it is totally opposed by the Government. Service allowance of $716 was granted recently, which is about $1 an hour for every hour of overtime worked throughout the year. The flying allowance claim is not yet before the Tribunal. Out of 70,000 service men and women 87 are in receipt of an education allowance. A serviceman may receive a removal allowance of $470 every time he moves house, which is approximately once every two years. There are long hours of work-52 to 55 hours a week on average, none of it recognised. There is increasing turbulence in the Services to plug the gaps appearing because of resignations and other wastage.

Housing in the Defence Force is a disgrace, as honourable members are well aware. Out of a total of 22,000 defence houses 12,000 are substandard, by the Defence Force's own admission. Maintenance on many of them is absolutely non-existent. I repeat the story of a friend of mine living in a service house in Townsville. Recently he fell through the floor of his bathroom because it had simply rotted away. Barracks are substandard. There is no removals allowance for single personnel. Working wives are not recognised. The Hamilton report was going to fix all these things for families. It is 1 1/2 years old and, of the 15 major recommendations, not one has been acted on. Defence service housing is the biggest fiasco of the lot in recent days. In the Budget the Government announced it would make changes. It has substantially downgraded the matter and there were near riots in camps throughout this country because once again servicemen had waited for the Government to act and they saw the Government act to their detriment.

It is not as though the Government has not had advice from the service chiefs. Senior officer after senior officer has said to the Government, `We can no longer continue to function with this wastage'. Yet in the Budget the Government cut another 900 personnel from the manpower levels. General Bennett, recently retired Chief of the Defence Force, has given the warning to the Government. General Gration, the present Chief, has said the same thing. Air Marshal Funnell, Chief of the Air Staff, has said that the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) is in a tight spot. Air Vice-Marshal Bradford has given warning as recently as last week that the experience level in the RAAF is being dangerously denuded. Admiral Hudson, the Chief of Naval Staff, says that equipment is meaningless unless we have adequate personnel. General O'Donnell, the Chief of the General Staff, expressed the same concerns. General Fitzgerald, the Deputy Chief of the General Staff, in the Estimates hearings last week was critical of manpower shortages. Air Marshal Newham, former Chief of the Air Staff, says that we desperately need more pilots and technicians. The advice to the Government last week by General Jeffery from the 1st Division was that that Division can be sustained in the field for four weeks-and that is one brigade. There are three brigades in the Division. God help us if they all had to be put into the field. The Government's response to this has been to discredit a fine soldier and a very able commander. It is only because of the calibre of men such as General Jeffery and the troops up there that the Government is able to run these exercises at all. The Government is using the Army Reserve to prop up the Regular Army instead of allowing our reserve forces to perform the tasks that they should be doing.

The effects of all this are quite severe. We are becoming an impotent force in our own area and our reduced manpower is leading to seriously reduced capabilities. We have limited troop lift equipment to take stores or troops to other parts of Australia or overseas. A landing craft squadron has been disbanded because there is no manpower to run it and a medium artillery battery and an anti-aircraft troop have also been disbanded. Royal Australian Air Force squadrons are almost grounded in some cases and the Army is incapable of taking the field for any length of time.

Front line units are undermanned and infantry battalions on Exercise Diamond Dollar are running at about 70 men in the company when they should be running at about 120 or 130 men, and platoons are running at 15 men when they should be running at 30 to 40 men. Batteries have been disbanded, and the Royal Australian Navy is desperately short of technicians and project managers for two of the biggest defence projects in this country-the submarine project and the frigate project. In fact, when asked, 88 per cent of naval officers say that they are thinking of resigning. Last week during the Estimates Committee hearing Rear-Admiral Ralph said that the landing craft squadron had been disbanded simply because there was not enough manpower.

When one turns to the RAAF where does one start? There are shortages in the F18 squadrons, shortages in the F111 squadrons, mass resignations from the transport squadrons at Richmond, and half to two-thirds of qualified flying instructor positions at Richmond to train extra pilots are vacant. Air Marshal Funnell, the Chief of the Air Staff, quite rightly says that the RAAF is in a very tight spot. It is not just that we are short of personnel-it is causing enormous costs in retraining. In fact, on average it costs $35,000 to train a recruit. To train a pilot to the stage where he reaches his first squadron costs about $2m, and by the time he has about 1,000 flying hours the cost is $6m. If we lose 300 pilots in the coming year, at an average cost of $4m each, the total cost would be $1.2 billion.

I will conclude by describing what should be done-and done quickly. First, we should reassess the priorities between spending on personnel and spending on equipment. Secondly, the Government must show that it cares by taking positive action in relation to the men and women who are serving in our defence forces and looking to the Government for assistance. Thirdly, the Government must implement the Hamilton report and stop mucking around with it, which is what it has been doing for the past 18 months. For God's sake, the Government must put some decent money into housing and give people accommodation in which they can live with pride. The Government must stop fiddling the figures by using half the housing money for new base projects, and it must stop opposing the payment of decent pay and allowances. The Government must recognise the long hours and the difficulties and dangers, the separation and the dedication of these men and women who are serving the Government.

Further, the Government must make sure that there is a meaningful education allowance so that people can educate their children decently and not have to scrounge around to get an education for their children, because that makes them look and feel as though they are second class citizens. The Government must give the issue of flying allowances some sort of priority before the Tribunal and must stop mucking around with the defence service housing loan which so many people look on as their right for the years to come.

For God's sake, the Government must act in these matters and, if it does, it will have our support. If it cannot act or will not act it should move over and let someone who can recognise the responsibility, particularly to the men and women of our defence forces, have a go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate some of the comments, particularly the concluding remarks, that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) made. In fact very many of the points that he has raised are exactly the points that I am working on implementing. But there is one thing that basically I do not understand about the honourable member's speech. How on earth would the Opposition, if it were in government, ever implement any of the proposals that he has put up as recommendations to this Government?

SPEECH.PARA: Just this week we have had calls from the Opposition to further reduce Government spending and to oppose totally any wage increase for wage and salary earners in this country. So, how on earth could we implement all of these wonderful recommendations? In fact, as I said, I and this Government support many of these recommendations and I am working to implement them. Members of this Opposition stand up here and piously say, `We care for our defence forces'. Believe it or not, I do too. But I have to do something about it and I will do something about it. We hear all sorts of pious claims from the Opposition. On the one hand, it says that we should do this that and the other. On the other hand, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) says that we should cut back Federal Government expenditure and that we should have no wage increase. Where does a policy like that leave the poor soldiers and sailors of this country? I will talk about this Government's record in a moment, but what is the Opposition's record? What did the Fraser Government do about salaries? It imposed a wage freeze. There was a consistent erosion of conditions. I will tell honourable members opposite that the housing rot set in when the present Opposition was in government. Between 1979-80 and 1982-83, in the years the Opposition was in government, $93.5m in January 1987 prices was spent on housing. How much do honourable members opposite think that we have spent on housing in the last four years? We have spent $211.4m. We have had to make up for the total neglect by this Opposition-when in government, of defence service homes-let alone salaries and conditions of service.

Although the Opposition says that we should cut back Government expenditure, the honourable member for McPherson says that we should spend money on the Defence Force. Basically, his main criticism is that we are spending too much money on capital projects. I would like the Opposition to tell me and to tell the Government what capital projects it wants to cut out. Does it want the new submarines, the 39 Black Hawk helicopters, the eight new light patrol frigates, the 6,000 radios for the Army, the 75 FA18 fighter aircraft, the 16 Sea Hawk helicopters for the Navy, the 67 new PC9 training aircraft for the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF), the 3,000 trucks for the Army, or the 3,240 light machine guns and the 67,000 rifles? If the Opposition does not want them, it should tell us what it wants in terms of its policy. The Opposition wants us to spend more money on service conditions. I support that and I will be doing what I can about it. The Opposition says, `We do not support salary increases, we want to cut back Government expenditure', but it will not tell us what capital projects it wants chopped out. It should tell us what capital projects it wants chopped out.

There has been a lot of discussion about people leaving the Services and about separation rates. I am trying to put this matter into some sort of perspective. There is no doubt that we have a problem in certain areas-for example, in respect of pilots. I am seeking, with Air Marshall Funnell, to address that. But over the last 10 years about 11.1 per cent of service personnel have turned over every year-that is, about one-third of the whole of the Defence Force has turned over during the last 10 years. As I said at Question Time, this has happened for all sorts of reasons-not just because people are resigning but because they are pensionable, sick or have been on short term appointments. That figure has now gone up to 12.8 per cent. So, on a 10-year average, we are up about 1.7 per cent. I think there are some reasons for that. One is that there are more women serving these days and they are more inclined to leave. There are more reservists who are coming in and then leaving and there are more trainees.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—There is no doubt that it is a factor. It is not the only reason, but it is a factor. Basically, what we have to do is to analyse the facts and look at where there are problems. We have identified that one of the key areas in which there are problems is definitely the pilot area. Current rates of pilot separations are much more than the Government and the Air Force would like. The 20-year average loss rate is 47 a year. In 1985-86, it was 70; in 1986-87, 107 and so far this year it is already 75. The problem is that we have not been training enough pilots to make up for those leaving. On average we have been training between 55 and 65 a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Why are they leaving? There are all sorts of reasons, but one of the key things is that there is a world-wide demand for pilots. Qantas Airways Ltd is actively recruiting at the moment. That is a big factor. Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd is also recruiting. We have a voluntary Defence Force. I will not tell our Defence Force pilots that they have to stay in the Defence Force and cannot go to Qantas. But what I do want and what I think this Government and this country have a right to expect is that we have sensible discussions with Qantas about how it can meet its needs without impinging on our operations of the Air Force. We have already had some discussions and they have been very useful. What we have tried to do is minimise the impact of continuing losses from RAAF to Qantas on RAAF operational activities. Pilots are very expensive to train.

We have done a number of things internally because the issue must be approached from both sides. I do not blame Qantas for the fact that Defence Force pilots are leaving, but there is no doubt that its increased recruitment is a factor involved. What we have done internally is increase the return of service obligation to eight years. The Chief of the Air Staff and I have had discussions about how we can improve the working environment. We are working towards increasing the compulsory retiring age for pilots of wing commander rank and below to 55 years. Also, we hope to introduce a limited air crew specialisation scheme, and we are working towards adopting policies designed to widen promotional opportunities for non-pilots in areas such as personnel and materiel to reduce demand for pilots in staff posts.

We are concerned about the pilot problem, but we are acting. We are not whinging, whining and complaining about it; we are acting to solve the problem. The way to work our way out of this is to train our way out. That is the only way we can do it. We must acknowledge the problem, look at the working conditions of our pilots and train more young people going through the ranks to fill the gap. We have to work with Qantas to ensure that it has more rational recruitment which does not impinge on our operations. I wish now to say something about the conditions of service. I am sick to death of hearing the honourable member for McPherson say that we are undermining conditions. That is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense.

—It is absolute nonsense. This Government has a commitment to improving the conditions of service of defence service personnel. I have just outlined the sort of money we have spent in the defence housing area. Tonight we will introduce a very important Bill-the Defence Housing Authority Bill-which will establish a more rational way of servicing and repairing our defence homes, as well as for putting more money into building new ones. Also, we have supported an increase in salaries for our defence Services. In fact, the anomalies case in 1985 gave the defence Services a 5.9 per cent increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Our approach to wages and salaries, basically, has been to look at allowances. Recently, we have seen an increase of over 100 per cent in the submariners allowance. The field allowance has been increased from $4.01 to over $12. The hearing for the flight allowance is about to start. I refer also to the increase in the service allowance of 22 per cent. Although there are problems within our economy, we have supported these increases, despite the Opposition's view that there should be no increase for wage and salary earners. We have been able to give priority to these things and to conditions of service. I will continue to tackle these issues.

I have been in charge of this portfolio for three months. I assure the House that I am committed to the implementation of many aspects of the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses. It seems to me that a couple of the key areas of concern to defence personnel and their families-we do not consider defence force personnel in isolation from their families-are posting frequency and education. A report on posting policy generally supported the current posting policy, but it stated that some modifications could be made to make it easier for defence service personnel. I have already discussed these issues with the Chief of the Defence Force. We are looking at the detailed recommendations of that inquiry.

Obviously, one of the other areas of major concern is education. I think it is important to address the key issue of providing education and education stability, particularly for older children in their last years of high school. There is the education allowance, as the honourable member for McPherson said. The take-up rate of that allowance is very low. I am now looking at the details to see whether we can do anything about that, having regard to the financial restrictions that we all face. I assure the House of my commitment to improving the morale and conditions of defence service personnel and their families.

I want to say something about operational capabilities. The honourable member for McPherson is incorrect in asserting that there has been a reduction in the operational capabilities of the Australian Defence Force (ADF).

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a reduction, a massive reduction.
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson has had his opportunity to address the House and will remain silent. He cannot continue to interject with impunity.

—This Government has put in place, for the first time in this nation's history, a comprehensive build-up in Australia's Defence Force, tailored to our unique strategic circumstances-something the Opposition failed to do, and continues to fail to do, now that it is in opposition. It totally neglects the whole concept of Australian defence. This Government is having realistic regard for our unique strategic circumstances and the economic realities. In order to achieve a balance in regard to investment in new capabilities, we are looking to the future for the Defence Force, to ADF operations with emphasis on credible contingencies. We are redressing the Opposition's neglect of critical issues such as service housing and single living accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite failed this country. They did not provide this country with a viable defence force, capable of defending the nation, its sovereignty and its vital interests. They failed because they failed to recognise where the defence of this country was heading. They have failed to do that even today. The Opposition's policy in this area is one of whining, groaning and trying to hit at various aspects of Government policy. But overall, it has no basic commitment to defence policy. It has no real understanding of where defence policy in this country should be headed. Instead, it has allowed itself to be mesmerised by aircraft carriers and expeditionary forces overseas. It has ignored the vital need to develop a joint force concept for our security.

This Government has now developed the strategy and force structure plan to meet credible threats to the nation. This Government is not just addressing the real threat; it is also addressing issues that are of concern to all defence personnel in this country. It is committed to the defence forces; it is committed to the defence of this country; and it totally rejects the assertion of the Opposition that the Government is treating the members of our defence forces like second-class citizens. We value our Defence Force. We value its members and their families who give them support. It is those families whose conditions I am working to improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate concerns the Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy, and the Royal Australian Air Force-I put them in that order because I am a little prejudiced-which have been recognised internationally as having the finest servicemen in the world. But the defence of this country, it is recognised, is running down to alarming levels. In spite of the dubious, misinformed and uninformed explanations from Government Ministers, including, regrettably, the new Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), the fact is that this country's service men and women are leaving the forces in droves.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons they are leaving are simple. They are fed up with service conditions that in no way compare with civilian standards and that in no way compensate for the dedication they show and the real sacrifices they make. They are leaving because they are convinced that this Government has turned its back on them. They know that the Government needs to do more than simply create a high flying ministerial title to rectify a problem that besets the service people and their families. Having a Minister in Canberra does not by itself solve the problems of remuneration, housing and the family turbulence caused by endless transfers from one post to another, nor does it provide in itself an answer to the problems of the career path that confront many middle ranking service men and women. Answering these problems takes more than a pretty ministerial title. It requires commitment. It is that lack of commitment that has caused the personnel wastage, the resignation problem.

In 1986 over 9,000 service men and women left the Australian defence forces. Many left before they were due to retire. In the first nine months of this year 7,287 voted with their feet and left for civvy street. In other words, out of a total complement of close to 70,000 service men and women, over 16,000 have left the forces in the last 21 months. The 823 who left the Services in August 1987 is the highest figure for August on record. Prior to 1986, monthly resignation figures had reached 1,000 only once-that was in January 1982, when I was not the responsible Minister. In the past 21 months that figure has been exceeded on four different occasions. No wonder the Government has decided not to publish monthly reports detailing personnel turnover. Why would it? Here we are spending billions of dollars each year on new equipment to make sure that we are at the forefront in modern military technology-we have the Australian Defence Force Academy and so on-yet we cannot seem to find the money to keep people in the Services. It is not hard to understand why they are leaving.

Australia's service men and women are totally professional. Let us look back. General Westmoreland stated during the Vietnam War that the Australian Army was the finest Army in the world. For a United States General to describe our forces in that way indicates that what I am saying is totally correct. Our forces are totally professional and dedicated. Yet since November 1981 there has been only one Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal decision favouring an increase in pay for these same service people. That was in 1985 and it amounted to a lousy 5.9 per cent instead of the 12 per cent recommended by the Defence Force advocate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is as bad as the parlia- mentarians.

—Parliamentarians are having the same experience. Service pay has not caught up from the onset of the wages pause way back in 1982. It shows no sign of catching up if the recent decision on service allowances is any indication. In recent years the Government has squashed any prospect of a real increase in the rate of remuneration, preferring to tinker with service allowances. Even here there has been immense disappointment. Some of the allowances have been increased, but the most significant allowance, the general service allowance, which compensates for such things as overtime, was extremely disappointing for members of the Services when it was announced a few months ago. How much do honourable members think the Government gave them? It gave them $7, which was way below expectations. We will find that most service men and women are working longer hours because there are not enough people to do the work. We will find that more and more people are leaving because they are sick and tired of working long hours for little remuneration.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the question of housing. The Department of Defence (DOD) owns or controls 22,000 houses around Australia specifically for our service families. Indeed, the DOD estimates that, of its 22,000 houses in stock, close to 15,000 are below standard. The Government spoke of providing $750m for service housing over a period of 10 years. That works out at something like $75m a year, but when we see that close to $30m of that money is going to Tindal, a new base in the Northern Territory and a much needed defence facility-my theme song is `Defence of the north'-we realise that only $45m of this year's allocation is going to the rest of the housing stock around the country. It might seem a lot of money, but it spreads thin when it gets down to the basics-the unrepaired windows, the shoddy carpets and the crowded children's bedrooms. These are the things our defence families have to put up with.

One of the most disturbing features of the present personnel wastage crisis is the number of middle ranked officers who are leaving the forces. In the first six months of this year, 64 male officers resigned from the Navy, 153 male officers resigned from the Army and 146 male officers resigned from the Air Force. They are very disturbing figures. Last year 798 male officers resigned from the forces-a number way up on the 395 who resigned in 1983, the last grace year for the defence forces. We had a damn good Defence Minister in those days.

Something is wrong. Besides service conditions such as pay, housing and postings, many middle ranked officers are getting out because there is no positive direction for them in the Services. If we take away their sense of direction, if we take away the path they like to follow, what happens to morale? It begins to fall apart. The centralised nature of the defence forces which sees officers naturally gravitate to desks at Russell deters many officers from pursuing their careers to their logical outcome. Instead, they get out. Pilots who are condemned to pushing pens in Fort Fumble leave to fly airliners for Qantas Airways Ltd, Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, Garuda Indonesian Airways, Ansett Airlines of Australia or Australian Airlines. They go where they can continue to fly and where they are paid a lot more for it.

We have lost so many pilots in the last few years-honourable members should listen to this-that we do not have enough pilots to fly our military aircraft, and this at a time when we have the finest aircraft in the world, the FA18, which our Government had the good sense to purchase. We spend millions on the new FA18s and we do not have the pilots to fly them. Similar problems of career development confront the Army and the Navy, the problems being how to develop career paths reflective of the professional and technical expertise evidenced in our defence forces. I see that the DOD has embarked on a career development path for its engineers. This is a worthwhile step, but it must be quickly expanded to include other professional and technical areas of the Services.

The costs to Australia of this rundown in our defence forces are enormous and terribly worrying. Honourable members do not have to listen to me to know that in a paper prepared by the Australian Chief of the Defence Force himself, and given to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in January 1987, the implications were clearly spelt out. He stated:
The increased wastage rates are impacting adversely on the Services as increasing resources are diverted into recruiting and training functions to allow increased training rates.
Administration and other costs are also increasing and experience levels are being diluted . . . Recruiting shortfalls also support the conclusion that young people,-
I ask honourable members to listen to this-
both civilian and Service, view the RAAF as relatively a much less attractive employer now than only two years ago.
I would have had much more to say, but time does not permit me. It is an appalling situation. It is absolutely distressing.
