TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—This man is a pacifist, for heaven's sake! He wants to abolish the Army.

—I expected to hear those interjections from the honourable member for Gippsland because as I rose to speak I heard him plotting with some of his rich private schoolboy mates to attempt to interject in the course of my remarks. Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure you that my contribution to this debate will be rather different from the sort of contribution which the honourable member for Gippsland repeatedly makes in this House-a contribution which demeans both himself and his own Party.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has indicated, the defence forces of Australia make tremendous sacrifices, for the people of Australia, not just in times of war but also in peacetime. We have great cause to be proud of the work that they perform. It is for that reason that we, as members of the Australian Parliament, are entrusted with a special responsibility to do all we can to advance their conditions of service. While I applaud the Opposition for at least raising this matter for debate in the House today, I wish that its expressed intentions were reflected in the standing which it has given to its shadow spokesman on defence. I hope that he would agree that a shadow spokesman on such an important topic as defence ought to be in the shadow Cabinet. The fact of the matter is that he is not; he is a well-intentioned but lowly ranking member of the Opposition front bench. I put it to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that if he really wants to establish some credibility with the defence forces of Australia he ought to elevate the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) to the front bench because until he does the Opposition will not have credibility when its members rise to speak about defence issues.

Having said that, let me put on the record the advances of this Government in relation to serving the defence personnel of Australia. What I do not want to do in the course of what I have to say is to raise expectations or to play phoney political games in this debate. As we in the Government recognise, as the Minister said today, of course there are problems in the defence forces that need to be addressed. Of course there are problems. It is for that reason that we, as members of the Hawke Labor Government, have, for the first time in the history of the Commonwealth of Australia, appointed a Minister directly responsible to the Parliament as a whole for service personnel matters. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), as we all know, commands the ear of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). She is someone who can get things done. She is someone who will be-she has already shown herself to be-an ally of defence personnel and their families. For the record, let me remind the House that she is, as I recall, the first woman Minister in the House of Representatives since Dame Enid Lyons-such is her standing in the Australian Labor Party.

The fact that we have a Minister directly responsible for Service personnel matters will not, of itself, as the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) said, change anything. What we have got to do is put together a package of programs that will seek to address the concerns and meet the real needs of service personnel and their families. I strongly agree with what the honourable member for Kennedy and, in part, what the honourable member for McPherson had to say about rates of pay and service allowances in the defence forces. There should be improvements.

Again, I remind the House that for the first time ever in the history of our country, service allowances and defence salaries are no longer a political football. It is not possible for this Government to bring about a wage freeze, as the Fraser Government sought to do, because for the first time there is an independent, statutory tribunal which can hear the claims of defence personnel for increased salary and allowances. That is a tremendous advance. I agree that that tribunal should listen very closely to what I believe are the just claims for increases in salaries and allowances. Being a member of the armed forces is a tough life. It is extremely hard on families when soldiers are away, often for many months at a time, and are forced to work long and fairly erratic hours. It is a very tough life. It deserves to be well remunerated and to be remunerated in a form comparable to salaries and allowances in civilian life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to do something about it?

—I put it to the shadow Minister that the Government does not set the salary levels. We have taken it out of the hands of the politicians-Liberal, National Party or Labor-and, for the first time, given it to an independent tribunal to review the allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that there are a lot more things that ought to be put on the record in the course of this debate. One is that for the first time within the ranks of the Government there is an organised group of members of Parliament that we call the Government Members Defence Force Action Committee which is committed to taking a stand, even if it means at some political cost to its members within the Government, to fight for service conditions and the rights of service families.

I came into this Parliament to fight for social justice. There ought to be social justice in the ranks of service personnel and their families. One of the great problems has been that often army bases and communities in which there are substantial numbers of service personnel and their families have been notoriously neglected, not just by this Government, but by governments going right back through the entire history of this country. One of the reasons such places have been neglected is that there has been tremendous movement by service personnel and their families to different parts of Australia. They do not have the opportunity to build up the community links, the power base and the lobbying techniques that we in civilian life are fortunate enough to have. For that reason in the past they have missed out on child care, neighbourhood centres, transport and a whole range of things that we in civilian life take for granted. That is changing. Why is it changing? It is changing because the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) established the Hamilton Review of the Effect of Service Life on Spouses. That report is being implemented by action taken to establish the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff. It is changing because we have now got an organised national lobby group of Service spouses called the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses. TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Amendment Bill 1987. It is interesting that this Bill is now going through the House of Representatives for the second time. It has been forced to be re-presented because of some deficiencies in the drafting of the Bill that went through earlier in the year which, in itself, appeared to be a fairly simple Bill. I think one can say that perhaps the parliamentary draftsman has some egg on his face in relation to this matter.
—Yolk, yolk!
—Between the Deputy Leader of the National Party and the honourable member for Mackellar this is really becoming a bit of a cackle, is it not?

—Since the Bill was passed earlier this year it has become obvious that because of variations in State hen quota practices there is doubt as to the adequacy of those provisions of the Act which define the application of the levy. For example, the Act imposes a levy on quotas as indicated in the licence held by the egg producer. However, in some States the quota is not specified in the licence. In Western Australia egg producers are allocated a base quota and a lower operative quota. Such a system allows the operative quota to be varied during the season depending on demand. The proposed changes will establish clearly that the levy applies to operative hen quotas-that is, the actual hen keeping entitlements-irrespective of how and where these are specified under State or Territory administrative procedures. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to speak in support of the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Amendment Bill. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has already explained, the purpose of this Bill is to overcome drafting anomalies. My involvement is both constituency-based and personal. As a youth growing up in the western suburbs of Sydney where there is a concentration of many egg producers, it was my pleasure to work as a lad on the Carney poultry farm, as well as Donnelly's poultry farm. The benefit of that experience comes in handy when dealing with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and some of his contributions in committees.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important Bill. Today I want to congratulate the New South Wales Government on all the progress that has been made in this industry and also to acknowledge the very worthwhile contribution made by egg producers not only in New South Wales but Australia-wide. It is a sad fact that changes in technology and the difficulties that the industry was in have resulted in approximately 1,500 producers in New South Wales leaving the industry over the last 13 years.

This Bill reflects the orderly marketing approach that has been adopted by the Government and, more particularly, by State governments. There was a referendum of all legal egg producers in New South Wales in 1982. It is interesting that some 98 per cent of legal producers voted, with a majority of 93 per cent for production control. On 1 July 1983, following the Gilchrist Committee on the Production and Marketing of Eggs in New South Wales, the Government in New South Wales decided to abandon the Egg Marketing Board and establish the Egg Corporation. In a fairly short history, I think that Corporation has done particularly well for the producers and the consumers of New South Wales. I point out that the previous coalition policies in that State resulted in ever-increasing prices to consumers, as well as the fact that we were exporting more and more egg pulp at significantly increased losses. One might say that it was an economists nightmare. That has changed significantly. How brave were the producers who voted overwhelmingly for orderly marketing. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the Egg Corporation-a $100m enterprise-the hen levy has come down from about $6.10 to $2 to $3 per hen. We have significantly reduced exporting egg pulp losses.

It is interesting to pose the question: Why should there be an orderly marketing system particularly as in New South Wales there are so-called rebel egg producers seeking a complete deregulation of the market? The majority of egg producers in New South Wales and, indeed, Australia, are small family concerns. There is a high degree of vertical integration not only in the egg production industry, but also in the egg meat industry. Without orderly marketing we are putting at risk the very existence of those who remain in the industry.

Mr Tebbutt, a rebel egg producer, in an electorate that adjoins mine, has made pleas for a free and deregulated market, but he never advises the public or the consumers that he received approximately $600,000 when he sold his quota. In other words, when he was in the system, enjoying the benefits of it, he opted to go out but he netted approximately $600,000, and he wants to argue for a deregulated market.

I know honourable members will be very pleased to learn that Choice magazine, on 23 February 1986, devoted a significant chapter to the production of eggs. I will quote to the House a few introductory paragraphs:
Consider a moment the credentials of an egg. A staple food for almost 5000 years, each one is packed with protein, fats, water and essential vitamins and minerals.
Eggs are versatile . . . fried, poached, boiled or scrambled, they cater to a wide range of taste preferences.
And they're useful. Cakes, custards and mayonnaise (to name a few) wouldn't be the same without eggs thickening and binding action.
Eggs are convenient-they can be cooked and served in less than five minutes-and they come in remarkably strong, compact packaging (even if they aren't square yet!).
Over the centuries eggs have been recognised as more than just a food source. They've been collected, preserved, ornately decorated, given as gifts and treasured.
They are a symbol of fertility and, in the Christian tradition, of new life.
How much must you pay for something that can do and be so many things? If it's the gold and jewel encrusted Faberge style egg you're after, you could pay as much as US$1,760,000 at auction.
The humble hen's egg, served up with toast for breakfast, can be yours for only 15 cents.

That is a useful introduction to the egg industry in that article. The same article pointed out that in New South Wales, the Egg Corporation and consumers are doing very well, as a dozen eggs cost $1.63 there, while in Queensland, the same product costs $1.74.

One of the other interesting things that I should point out, in talking about the efficiency of the Egg Corporation, is that if one looks at the vegetable and fruit marketing system that operates in New South Wales, one sees that something like 67 per cent of the retail price is added on after the farm gate. In other words, producers are getting something like 33 per cent of the price and when finally the consumer buys the product, about 67 per cent has been added on. For eggs, the after farm gate retail add-on is only 35 per cent. That speaks volumes as far as the New South Wales Egg Corporation policies are concerned.

As I said, I am very proud to have had a personal association with this industry. I should also inform the House that, in the last Parliament, I was very concerned about vertical integration in the industry and I would like to commend the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for agreeing to launch an investigation by the Prices Surveillance Authority into the vertical integration of the chicken meat industry, in particular as it relates to the takeover by one of the major players of a number of hatcheries. I know that the industry has responded well to the Government's initiative in that regard, and the Prices Surveillance Authority is monitoring the situation. However, I would also warn of the dangers of excessive vertical integration as far as hatcheries are concerned, in egg production as well.

I am pleased to see that the Opposition is supporting the Bill; I certainly support it. I commend the Government for the action that it has taken and I commend States like New South Wales, which has diligently sought to protect the family producers while counterbalancing that by providing a first-rate quality product for consumers at the lowest possible price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure on what the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) was congratulating the Unsworth Labor Government in New South Wales about. I am not sure that many consumers would necessarily join in that congratulation. However, in a moment, I will come back to a recent joint initiative with the Victorian Government which is of some significance. In respect of the egg industry, what is before the House are certain amendments to the existing legislation to affirm the proper basis of charging a levy imposed on producers to finance research programs in the industry. No doubt much of that research will be directed towards increasing the technical efficiency of the industry and the productivity in the industry in terms of the eggs produced per laying hen. The end result of that will be that, while already more eggs-far more eggs-are produced than consumers want to buy, even more will be produced as that productivity goes up. I would say that it would be a very good idea if a significant portion of that research were directed towards a detailed study of the structure and the economics of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry is almost a classic case of the effects of collusive arrangements between producers in the form of a producers cartel, enforced by government fiat introduced into an otherwise highly competitive but potentially unstable industry, characterised by a relatively simple technology, a standard product, and, if unimpeded, easy entry for new producers. What happens is that, in the interests of `stabilisation', the cartel is formed and a production quota-or rather, in principle, a sales quota for fresh eggs in the Australian market-is assigned to each producer. By limiting the aggregate offering of eggs on the market, the price is controlled, typically, increased, and lifted to yield an adequate return to as many producers, egg farmers, as have gained access to the industry and accommodating, generally, even high cost producers.

In the egg industry, the first strike in controlling total production and sales is to provide for the imposition of hen quotes, as in the title of the Bill before the House, the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Amendment Bill. The Government, through the various egg boards, in effect issues licences specifying the number of laying hens which each producer might keep. This works initially; but the trouble then is that every effort-genetic, technological and otherwise-is bent on increasing the number of eggs laid per hen. Thus, even more eggs than people want to buy are produced, and the surplus eggs are processed to dried or powdered egg and other manufactured products and sold, principally abroad and generally at a loss. The pressure then is to lift the price of fresh eggs to the Australian consumer even further, limiting, via the marketing boards and the egg levy, the total offering of such eggs on the market to support that price.

It is a situation where one tends to get the rather perverse outcome, from an economist's point of view, that, with increased capacity and potential supply, one winds up with a higher price-rather than with a lower one as one would ordinarily expect with free competition in such circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is enough to make you boil.
—We have already talked about `eggsasperating' situations and others in this debate, so do not add to it.
—Keep it up and you will be shell shocked.
—My colleague--
—Made a bad `yolk'.

—Let us get back to business. There is this perverse outcome of increased capacity and supply at an even higher price, rather than the lower price that one would otherwise expect. One estimate by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics relating to a few years back was that the operations of the various State egg boards held up the price of eggs to about 40c above an efficient cost-price level. The price was then about $1.50 a dozen. On the basis that a freer market would lead to a price more approaching such a level, that would mean that the consumer was subsidising the egg producer to the extent of 40c a dozen eggs. It is fair to say on the other side that these arrangements ensure that there is always an adequate supply of eggs to the Australian consumers, available at reasonably stable prices, and the arrangements have the effect of maintaining a larger number of small, family producers in the market than would otherwise be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Overall it is a rather complex industry and it is important that the House take this on board. As I said, the purpose of the legislation before the House is retrospectively to regularise practices which vary somewhat as between the States and the Northern Territory for imposing the egg industry research levy, making it clear that this is to be assessed by multiplying the unit levy by operative hen quotas-actual hen keeping entitlements. While the existing structure of the egg marketing boards is in place, the Opposition, and I, accept that this legislation is necessary. Explicit notice was given to all boards that this change was intended, and it would have been made in the autumn session of Parliament had not the election intervened. The operative words are `while the existing structure of marketing boards is in place'. As I said before, it would be a good idea if some of the proceeds of this research levy were applied to detailed research on the structure and economics of the industry and how the existing arrangements might be modified in the interests of lower prices to the consumers and yet still allow adequate returns to the producers.

Mr Ross Gittins, the economics writer of the Sydney Morning Herald, recently wrote a very interesting article on the industry. Mr Gittins, in my book, has an honoured place amongst economics writers for the very insightful immediate response to the recent August Budget that he made in the midst of all the surrounding Press euphoria. I quote a bit of it. It started off:
Good old Paul, always got another rabbit in his hat: this time, a balanced Budget and we didn't feel a thing.
Not bad, eh? Well, not bad, but not as good as it looks.
He went on to make some very insightful comments-and we are talking about the very morning after the Budget-and he concluded in this vein:

Senior ministers plan to take a long holiday over Christmas. That should bring them back refreshed, ready to start work on a tough, post-election mini Budget next May-the sort of shocker we should have had last night.

That is, on 15 September! With the grave events of the past week, I think the luxury of the long Christmas holiday might not be on. However, I mention that Mr Gittins wrote that very insightful article and he also has written a piece on the egg industry. Rather than go into it in detail I draw the attention of the House to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 October. He reports there a proposal that did not get much publicity elsewhere; namely, the announcement by the New South Wales and Victorian Ministers for Agriculture that the New South Wales Egg Corporation and the Victorian Egg Board would merge their manufactured product divisions through the formation of a wholly-owned subsidiary called Good Food Products Australia Pty Ltd. He went on to report that there was some anticipation that this proposed joint manufactured egg product facility would become a significant episode in privatisation, that this might result ultimately in the dismantling of the complex structure of regulation in the industry-including fresh eggs, not just the manufactured products-and more effective competition in the industry with the effect that egg prices might be brought down to more reasonable levels. He was not too optimistic about the success of this development. It is, of course, early days and most of the real nitty gritty as to how that might be done has not yet been worked out. I refer honourable members to his article and merely commend Mr Gittins on it. I express the hope that he maintains his watching brief over the progress of this proposal for merging and, maybe, for the privatisation and deregulation of the nation's principal egg marketing authorities. Meanwhile, as I said, some detailed economic research would not go amiss.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Bill which are being debated today seek to impose an annual levy on all borrowings by Commonwealth semi-government authorities other than those engaged primarily in the business of financial intermediation; for example, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. Let me say at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose the Bills. However, there are several points I wish to raise in relation to the introduction of this new levy. This levy was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his 1987-88 Budget Speech and it replaced the Commonwealth guarantee charge which was imposed in 1986-87 on borrowings by authorities that were subject to an explicit Commonwealth Government guarantee. That earlier guarantee charge was, the Government then explained, introduced to take account of the favourable interest rates paid by Commonwealth authorities where their borrowings are explicitly guaranteed by the Commonwealth. The Government's expressed objective in imposing the charge was to ensure that the effective cost of borrowings to authorities was more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers, thereby ensuring that authorities take full account of the cost to the community of their investment decisions. However, although the government claims that it is simply trying to remove an advantage from public enterprises that private enterprises do not have, the motivation for the legislation seems to be instead the desire simply to tap an extra source of revenue. Again this Government makes its grab for the cash.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that the current Government is the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. The Budget Papers tell us that for 1987-88 the Government intends to collect an enormous $78 billion in revenue. That is an increase in revenue over the previous year of some $5.9 billion. Indeed, it compares with only $44 billion collected under the last Fraser Government in 1982-83. So, during its period in office this Labor Government has increased its revenue collections by a massive 75 per cent. The Australian Labor Party may talk about its tax reform initiatives, but how does it explain to the Australian taxpayer a 75 per cent increase in the Government's income? It is the highest taxing, biggest spending government in the history of the nation. The fact is that this Government does not try to explain that. Instead, it keeps increasing revenue to fund unjustifiable programs that tie up valuable resources which otherwise could have been used by the private sector for more rewarding endeavours.

Faced with the enormous predicament of $83 billion in foreign debt-I remind the House that under the Hawke-Keating Government Australia's foreign debt has quadrupled in four years-this Government nevertheless refuses to make the quality spending cuts to force the pace of needed economic adjustment to prevent us, in the words of the Government's own Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, going further down the Argentinean road. These Bills, albeit on a small scale, represent just another example of a greedy government using every avenue it can to rake in the cash.

Let me return more specifically to the pieces of legislation now before the House. The introduction of this new legislation to replace the Commonwealth Guarantee (Charges) Act 1987-that legislation is not even a year old and already it is being replaced, which is yet another example of this Government being unable to think through the consequences of its action in that it introduced a charge last year and totally replaces it a year later-represents nothing less than an admission that the Opposition's reservations, as expressed during the second reading debate on the previous legislation, were well founded. In itself, the proposed legislation appears to be quite reasonable. Nevertheless, the previous legislation and its regulations, like much of the Government's legislation in the taxation arena, seem to have been hastily prepared and certainly ill-considered-frankly, just not thought through.

In addition, it is also worth noting that the regulations setting out the collection machinery for the previous charges were not presented to Parliament until just before the end of the last financial year-sloppiness yet again. In the process, the public authorities-and through them the taxpayers-have suffered due to the unreasonable costs imposed and the uncertainty caused by the unnecessary delays. Let us review a number of the changes made in the new legislation. Firstly, it was realised that financial institutions gain only a slight advantage, in terms of borrowing costs, from Commonwealth guarantees beyond that arising from their status as financial institutions. Therefore, they are now to be exempt.

Secondly, it was realised that a rate of half of one per cent on borrowing proceeds was too high, if not for all then at least for the large authorities such as Telecom Australia. Nonetheless, it is expected that the Government will charge the new lower rate of 0.125 per cent uniformly. This will not take account of the acknowledged difference in the benefit of a guarantee to different authorities. Indeed, it would appear reasonable that the guarantee is worth more to smaller authorities whose lesser borrowing requirements reduce the secondary market and therefore the tradeability of their securities. However, I recognise that in practice the differences are hard to judge for administrative purposes, and therefore to charge a uniform rate, at least for the first few years of the levy, is a satisfactory second best option-that is, given the Government's desire for a levy.

If I may digress on this point for a moment, the question of the differences in the value of the guarantee to various types of authority has certain other implications. It would seem obvious that, because some larger authorities such as Telecom have substantial annual borrowing requirements, the secondary market for their securities is of a reasonable size. By `secondary market' I mean the market that buys and sells existing bonds of varying maturity previously issued by an authority-and again let us use Telecom bonds as an example. Because such a market is fairly active, any person who has Telecom stock knows that he or she can sell that stock fairly promptly as a result of the well-established market of buyers and sellers. This contrasts with the situation for a smaller authority such as the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority (ACTEA), where securities issued in its name are fairly scarce and therefore the risk of holding them could be higher than for Telecom bonds. As a result, the ACTEA borrowing costs are higher and the yields that it must pay will inevitably be higher than for Telecom. I mention all this because it seems to me that there may be a case for a co-ordinated borrowing system that allows the loans of a number of Commonwealth authorities to be aggregated. Because of the larger volume involved, smaller authorities then might be able to obtain lower yields.

Virtually all States have what are called central borrowing authorities. Among others, there are the Victorian Public Authorities Finance Agency, the South Australian Financing Authority and the Treasury Corporation in New South Wales. Instead of a new body exactly like those for use by Commonwealth authorities, an alternative using existing institutions may-I emphasise `may'-be viable. Smaller authorities could simply contract out to have their borrowing task added into the larger borrowings of authorities such as Telecom on a type of consultancy basis. In that way they may be able to reduce their costs. Although that is only a germ of an idea at the moment, I suggest that it may be worth further consideration.

Returning to the legislation at hand, the third point that I make is that during the 1986-87 financial year it was found, as the Opposition expected, that, because only borrowings explicitly given Commonwealth guarantees were covered by the earlier Act, authorities-where they could-quickly began to realise that they should forgo obtaining guarantees. That is because it became obvious that the cost of funds to Commonwealth authorities appears to reflect an expectation by lenders that the Commonwealth will stand behind those authorities whether or not an explicit guarantee has been given. As a result, it has obviously proved to be inequitable to treat differently implicit and explicit guarantees, and that is especially the case when borrowings by some smaller authorities were almost all subject to explicit guarantees-so they did not have the opportunity to avoid the charge.

Indeed, this suggests that, while an authority is government owned, it will always have a safety net beneath it to prevent it from ever being truly commercial. That means that the Government's stated intention in introducing these Bills becomes moribund. The Government's argument, that a levy such as this on borrowings will remove an advantage to public borrowers over private business and therefore put them in an equal competitive position, does not necessarily follow. If the Government wants to make these authorities truly competitive, the most direct way to do it is to sell them to the private sector. Of course, the converse of that argument is: if the Government managed to attain a situation where an authority competed on a one-to-one basis with private enterprise-which I doubt is really possible-what social purpose is being supplied by the Government owning such an asset? The Opposition is committed to a rational policy of disposing of those authorities which will operate more effectively outside public ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear' indeed. Such a policy would be preferable to the Government's attempts to increase its revenue base by imposing additional costs on authorities, that is, costs that will eventually translate through to the consumer and impact directly, although marginally, on inflation through increases in charges. This Government's approach to budgetary policy is all on its head. It simply focuses on raising revenue rather than making the required expenditure reductions to release resources for needed adjustment to cope with our pressing economic difficulties. Finally, and notwithstanding these concerns, I reiterate that the Opposition will not oppose these Bills.

No doubt it is an issue which will receive full and proper public debate over the next few months in the various forums which exist certainly within the Government, within the Opposition and within the general community.

Previously the authorities have been operating under favourable interest rates because their borrowings were explicitly guaranteed by the Commonwealth. Of course, that tends to give something of an advantage to those authorities. Whether it was explicit or implicit, they were given some special place in the market-place. Of course, if we are talking about public sector authorities competing effectively in the private sector and vice versa, the playing rules must be the same for everyone, and this Government recognises that fact.

The decision taken in the Budget, to which this legislation gives effect, was a result of the review of the operation of the charge to which I have already made reference. Clearly it has become apparent that the status of being government owned conferred advantages on all authorities in financial markets simply because lenders expected that the Commonwealth would back up those authorities whether or not an explicit guarantee had been given. I think that really underlies what this legislation is about. There was an explicit expectation that there would be back-up services and guarantees given by the Commonwealth Government for the borrowing requirements of these public authorities. Therefore, the Government rightly, in my view, decided that the levy should be imposed on all borrowings by semi-government authorities from 1 July 1987. Of course, this will ensure that the community's fight against indebtedness is not endangered by these authorities being tempted to borrow more than absolutely necessary because of attractive interest rates.

Despite the events of the past week or so, despite the pressures within the economy and despite the fact that interest rates are coming down, it still was possible for these semi-government authorities perhaps to seek out a more favourable interest rate climate and to get some advantage within the general community simply because the lenders saw the Commonwealth Government as being the guarantor for each of those borrowings. I do not seek in any way, shape or form to cast aspersions upon the operators and the management of the semi-government authorities. That is certainly not my intention at all. What I am suggesting is that they saw some advantage in the market-place that perhaps might have existed, and the authorities which they were managing took full advantage of that. But it must be realised that the legislation is concerned with 21 commissions, corporations and authorities. Despite what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, most of those commissions, corporations and authorities are very large operations in the general market-place.

The schedule which is attached to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill lists 21 organisations and I will just quickly refer to some of them. They include Aussat Pty Ltd, the Australian National Airlines Commission-that is, Australian Airlines-the Australian National Railways Commission, the Australian Postal Commission, the Australian Telecommunications Commission, the Australian Trade Commission, the Federal Airports Corporation, the Health Insurance Commission, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia), Qantas Airways Ltd and, of course, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. They are all major public authorities. When one looks at the scale of the commissions and authorities about which we are talking and which are addressed by the legislation, we may very well have to conclude that the suggestion that they might improve their borrowing abilities and so on by being grouped together is not necessary. That is an issue which, I am sure, the Minister will take into consideration.

If all of those 21 various authorities took advantage of the interest rates offered to them, because of their government-owned status, our indebtedness would probably blow right out and our economic recovery would be jeopardised. I do not think that anyone could disagree with that. Quite simply, their borrowing must be assessed in a broader economic context. This legislation will ensure that that occurs. The levy will not apply to Commonwealth-owned financial institutions, such as the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. It has to be said that those financial institutions do not benefit from their government-owned status in the same way as the 21 authorities which are listed in the schedule to the Bill.

I wish to make a couple of comments about the contribution of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He led off the debate for the Opposition on the Bills this afternoon. It is appropriate to consider now his statement that this Government's concentration on revenue raising rather than reducing expenditure and so on is something which needs to be further addressed. I suggest to the House that through legislation such as this, which makes public authorities more accountable and, therefore, ensures that they more effectively compete in the market-place generally within both the public and private sectors, the whole question of the Government concentrating on revenue raising and not on reducing expenditure can be overcome. The whole argument that privatisation of publicly-owned enterprises will solve all the economic ills of Australia is not, in my view, a proposition which can be wholly sustained. There seems to be a view within the community-certainly it is the view of honourable members on the Opposition benches-that simply putting a publicly-owned operations into private hands, in a particular way and for a particular reason, is magic and that that enterprise will function far more efficiently and effectively.

I think that people who dwell in rural Australia would challenge that view as far as Telecom is concerned. I think that the majority of people in the poorer areas of Australia would disagree with that as far as the Health Insurance Commission is concerned. I am sure that many people would disagree with that in terms of their ability to get television reception or to send telephone messages around Australia. Those services are provided by organisations such as the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat and so on. Simply stating that the Government's strategy is wrong and that the only panacea to the problem is to sell all of those public authorities to the private sector is stating a question far too simply.

In addition, the honourable member for Kooyong said that this Government is the highest taxing government ever in Australia's history, that it desires to tap extra sources of revenue and that it expects to raise an extra $1.3m in 1987-88. One would not have thought that in the broader scale of things, in terms of revenue raised by this Government, that that was a great deal of money. But, nevertheless, it was said that that was the case. The honourable member went on to say that there had been no tax reform and, as the Government's tax take was so high, how could it talk of reform. What he forgot to mention, yet again, as he did when he spoke to some taxation Bills in this place the other day, was that our tax reform essentially brought into place some pieces of legislation which had a great bearing on the private sector. I am talking, of course, about the imputation system, the reduction in marginal tax rates and so on. He went on to say that the tax take which this Government has received has been the highest in 75 years, or words to that effect. That is probably right. But it is right because people who previously were not paying any tax, or certainly not their fair share of tax, are now starting to do so. That is a most important point that needs to be made about the observation of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in his very shallow response to this legislation this afternoon.

The Commonwealth guarantee charge will continue to operate on borrowings undertaken in 1986-87. The estimated revenue from that will be about $7.6m this financial year. I conclude by saying that the measure which the legislation seeks to enact integrates into this Government's broader economic strategy. That is an important part of the consideration of a lot of the measures that will come before the House over the next few weeks. It is part of the Government's broader economic strategy, a strategy that has seen the deficit reduced to a balanced Budget situation and that has seen the economic direction of this country thought through, despite claims to the contrary by those opposite. I believe that part and parcel of that strategy is the implementation of measures such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an example of one of those items of legislation that governments from time to time bring forward in order to, I suppose, tidy up the operation of public sector enterprises and, in a sense, to put them in a comparable position with the situation in which private enterprise finds itself, in this case in relation to their borrowing responsibilities and the type of interest that is charged on their borrowings. It is quite clear that as a result of either explicit or implicit guarantees which the Commonwealth provides for semi-government enterprises of one kind or another, lenders would be prepared, generally, to lend to those institutions at a lower rate of interest than normally would be charged for other examples of private enterprise where perhaps the guarantee and the security of those loaned funds could not be guaranteed with such certainty. Naturally enough, that places semi-government authorities in an advantageous position as far as their borrowings are concerned and as far as the cost of servicing those loans is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Frequently, the claim is made that, as a result of circumstances of this kind, semi-government enterprises find themselves in a position whereby they can compete unfairly against comparable operations in the private sector. Here is an example of a case in which a Labor government has indicated that the constraints on semi-government authorities will be of the same kind as those which operate in relation to private enterprise. What we are doing now is tidying up and consolidating the Government's intention that was provided initially when the old Commonwealth guarantee charge was introduced for 1986-87. That Commonwealth guarantee charge provided that an additional charge of up to 0.5 per cent on borrowings would be imposed by the Commonwealth on its semi-government authorities as a result of the benefit they enjoyed from explicit government guarantees for their borrowings in terms of the interest they were paying for funds that they raised for capital purposes. The Commonwealth guarantee charge was applied to all of those borrowings. The annual borrowing levy is now being introduced to replace that earlier arrangement. It will be paid by Commonwealth authorities when their borrowings are explicitly guaranteed by the Commonwealth and also when those borrowings are not explicitly guaranteed by the Commonwealth.

This legislation will put all Commonwealth authorities in essentially the same position. That did not occur with the previous arrangement that operated under the old guarantee charge scheme. It is simply based on the recognition that, whether or not the Commonwealth Government gives an explicit guarantee to any of its semi-government authorities for the purpose of their borrowing arrangements, the lenders, nevertheless, will be of the opinion that since they are Commonwealth enterprises, Commonwealth undertakings, there is an implicit guarantee. For that reason, it is reasonable to expect that private sector lenders, private financial institutions, will be prepared to lend to any type of Commonwealth Government enterprise at what is at least a marginally lower rate of interest. As a result, this is designed to ensure that the benefit accruing to semi-government authorities will be removed. They will play on an even field when they are in the market-place, in the commercial world, competing, particularly, against some of those private enterprises that have to pay a higher rate of interest in order to attract the funds that they want to borrow. This is a fairly significant change that the Government is introducing in order to overcome some of the deficiencies that existed in the previous arrangement.

I am pleased to see, in a sense, the initiative being shown by some of those public enterprises. They were rearranging their borrowing programs to ensure that no explicit Commonwealth guarantee was being provided for their borrowings in order to escape that earlier guarantee charge. But they were still getting the benefit of the fact that they were public enterprises. For that reason, the Government is, in a sense, closing a loophole around which the Government enterprises operated previously.

I want to emphasise, as well, that this levy which is now being imposed will be imposed on all borrowings, including raisings of money other than by borrowing, by all of those Commonwealth semi-government authorities. People may well ask: In addition to conventional-type borrowing, what other means are there for semi-government authorities to raise the money that they require? Of course, in addition to conventional domestic and overseas loan raisings, we also have deferred payment arrangements, overseas trade credits and financial leases. We also have, among some of the non-formal borrowing arrangements, sale and leaseback arrangements and instalment purchases. All of those are available to semi-government authorities, just as they are available to the rest of the community.

It is important for us to understand, as well, in relation to these borrowings, that it is necessary for the Treasurer to provide his approval for borrowings. Most often, of course, that authority by the Treasurer is a delegated authority.

All of those borrowings by semi-government authorities, as is the case for general borrowings by governments, are included in the public sector borrowing requirement and are also included within the global limits. This procedure and conceptual arrangement have now been adopted to ensure that some type of control or general restriction is placed on the total borrowings of the public sector.

The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) in his contribution referred to the fact that the gross public sector borrowing requirement as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) has been progressively reduced by this Government. In 1983-84 the gross public sector borrowing requirement as a percentage of GDP was 8 per cent; in the following year it was 7 per cent; in 1985-86 it was 5.8 per cent; last year it was 4 per cent; and this year we are budgeting for a figure of less than 3 per cent. I think it is important for people to understand that that trend has been maintained by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great achievement.

—As the honourable member for Stirling says, it has been a great achievement in terms of the particular difficulties that the Government faced when it came into office in March 1983. There are so many examples of this kind to which we can refer to show the adequacy of the response which has been made by this Government to ensure that the fundamentals of the Australian economy were put very firmly in place. There is no question about the very significant changes that have taken place. I have indicated that from 1983-84 until last year the reduction in the gross public sector borrowing requirement as a percentage of GDP went down from 8 per cent to 4 per cent, and the net public sector borrowing requirement as a percentage of GDP, during the same period, went down from 6.7 per cent to 3.8 per cent. So there have been very significant achievements in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been concerned, and has expressed its concern, not only in statements that have been made, but also in the policies which it has adopted, to ensure that the public sector should reduce its total call on the resources available within the community. I prefer not to differentiate between the call which is made by semi-government authorities, public enterprises, on the liquid reserves, the liquid savings, of the community, in order to finance its investment, and the call which is made by private sector operations, of a similar kind, operating in the market, competing, as I said before, on a level field and also making demands on those liquid resources that are available to the community. If they represent new investment, the creation of new productive facilities and an increase in the total national infrastructure, does it really matter very much whether it is undertaken by the private sector or by the public sector? We must get away from this cringe that suggests that in some way public sector investment is less desirable-indeed on some occasions, even less moral-than private sector investment. Such a suggestion, of course, is totally absurd.

When we look around an advanced country such as Australia we see that the Government has been fundamentally important in providing public enterprises, semi-government authorities of the kind that we have in Australia, and also the magnificent infrastructure which has been developed over 200 years, such as transport, ports, power generation, and facilities of that kind. So people should not always think the Government has a responsibility, necessarily and exclusively, to gear back the demands that are being made on the community's total liquid reserve. It is important that the great public enterprises which are affected by this legislation are given the opportunity to broaden their own capital base and to establish their own investment infrastructure, to make it possible for them to achieve those objectives, and to pursue those objectives, that the community rightfully expects from them. They may concern those areas that are called natural monopolies, such as those that are responsible for electricity and gas distribution, or Australia Post or Telecom Australia, or they may concern those areas which are more akin to private sector operations such as Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd or the Commonwealth Bank. Those bodies are all important and they all have an extremely important role to play.

When the initial legislation was introduced to establish the Commonwealth guarantee system which this legislation is now making provision to replace, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer at the time, the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), who introduced it said:

the purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition . . . of an annual charge on borrowings or other raisings of money by Commonwealth semi-government authorities which are guaranteed by the Commonwealth.
As I have said, it is not just those which are now guaranteed by the Commonwealth but those for which there is some sort of implicit guarantee as well. The then Minister went on to say:

This charge, which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in the Budget Speech, has regard to the favourable interest rates paid by Commonwealth authorities due to the fact that their borrowings are guaranteed by the Commonwealth. The main consequence of the charge will be to ensure that the effective cost of borrowings to authorities is more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers, thus ensuring that authorities take full account of the cost to the community of their investment decisions.

That lies at the base of this approach. It does not matter very much whether it is under the provisions of the Commonwealth guarantee charge or whether it is under the provisions of this new borrowing levy arrangement. The purpose is the same; to ensure that they are all operating on an even field. Most borrowers have to ask for a guarantee, especially where the borrowings are for a long term. For short term borrowing arrangements, generally less than 12 months, no guarantee is involved. So those institutional loans as well will be subject to this new levy.

The Commonwealth guarantee charge operated on the daily balance that was outstanding for each of those guaranteed loans. I indicated before that the amount of the charge is being reduced from 0.5 per cent which applied before to the new level of 0.125 per cent. It would appear that we are adjusting that in the light of market realities and as comparable interest rates. It appears-I am not able to confirm this-from an adjustment of that kind that we have discovered the degree of differential, which is less than 0.5 per cent, in the interest being charged on private sector borrowings and public sector borrowings for operations and authorities of a similar kind. As I have indicated, most markets do not recognise the difference between those implicit and explicit guarantees-nor should they.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right.

—As the honourable member for Stirling recognises, there is a clear recognition by those borrowers that whether the Commonwealth provides an explicit guarantee or not it will naturally stand behind its own semi-government authorities. I also indicated that one reason for this change to encompass all semi-government authority borrowings is that they were showing a commendable degree of initiative in adjusting their own borrowing arrangements in order to ensure that they did not require any explicit guarantee. As a result of that it was possible for those authorities to escape the payment of the former Commonwealth guarantee charge.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said when I began my speech, government operations of this kind are necessary from time to time to ensure that semi-government authorities operate in a way which is appropriate not only to the purposes of the public sector but also to the general expectations of the community. While the community should accept that investment by the public sector in building up national infrastructure is just as important-if it is productive, if it is needed, if it increases our productive capacity, if it enlarges employment, if it generates income, if it helps to promote our exports-as investment undertaken by other bodies there is no reason why, in a mixed economy of the kind we enjoy in Australia, it should not be necessary for the public sector to show its bona fides by accepting the same type of constraints, the same type of limitations, the same type of requirements that exist elsewhere. For reasons of that kind, I am pleased to support the legislation. It will ensure that public sector enterprises, semi-government authorities, those which are owned by the Commonwealth, will be expected to measure up-as they have traditionally been expected to measure up-with the expectations of the community concerning the sort of constraints that should operate on any type of business undertaking when it borrows and the sort of debt servicing charge that they should be expected to meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) in debates in this House. I have enjoyed listening to his remarks on the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill and the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Bill. Like the honourable member for Charlton, I think that there are many aspects of this Government's economic policy that we could refer to in this debate which show a sensible approach to economic management. I note the remarks of the honourable member for Charlton. The honourable member has covered a wide and effective range of the issues at stake.

SPEECH.PARA: For those who are listening to this debate, it is interesting that at a time of some economic turmoil in the market-place we are talking today about borrowings in the market-place and giving guarantees to those borrowings. So the remarks that we are making in this debate are quite pertinent given the current economic climate. It is also possible to observe in passing that the fundamentals in terms of the economic management of this economy are in good shape. For those who must surely be troubled by recent movements in the stock market, both here and overseas, it must be understood that we, as Government members, believe that the fundamentals in terms of economic management are well put in place and that we are confident about our stewardship of economic activity. Over the next few days there will be a further shaking out of the economic activity with a levelling of prices and some return to stability in the market-place. In contrasting ourselves with the United States of America, as the honourable member for Charlton well knows, we are in the fortunate position of having a domestic deficit which is barely perceptible now because of the 1987-88 Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is another great achievement.

—It is another great achievement. We are in that happy position, vis a vis that of the United States, of having our domestic deficit under control. That means that a lot of the fundamentals are in place to deal with these difficult economic circumstances. I think the task confronting the United States is very much to rein in its domestic deficit, and its external deficit. As the honourable member for Charlton has said in previous debates much is made of the question of the external deficit, which was raised by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). It is important to remind those opposite-the honourable member for Charlton has spoken about this as well-that a significant element-a bigger proportion-of the external deficit we have in Australia is, in fact, private sector induced. We do not have any particular axe to grind in that respect except to say that this is a natural occurrence when the economy has been opened up; it is a natural occurrence when the dollar is floated; and it is also a natural occurrence of the market forces and the entrepreneurial activity in Australia which has sought to raise those funds.

SPEECH.PARA: With the change in our attitude towards the taxation of dividends and now that we are moving towards a dividend imputation system-this is quite significant and people will recognise this-the benefits to equity raising within Australia can now be achieved in the longer term. So the need for external indebtedness in terms of the corporate sector will be reduced. Obviously, that is a long term sign for the Australian economy. If Australian corporations can raise money within the Australian market and not have to proceed off-shore there is a long term structural benefit to be achieved. The honourable member for Charlton has spoken on that and has recognised that very well. We recognise it on this side of the chamber as being a substantial achievement and a long needed economic reform. The honourable member for Kooyong brought up the question of the external sector. We can say that our taxation reform package generally is quite important.

The honourable member for Charlton also referred to the public sector borrowing requirement. What he said was quite correct. I endorse his remarks that we have achieved a great deal of fiscal responsibility. The public sector borrowing requirement has been reduced. It has not been an easy task. In the face of achieving wage restraint we have also had to achieve fiscal restraint at both the national and the State levels. That degree of fiscal responsibility and discipline has been achieved by this Hawke Government since 1983, and I think it is an achievement that we can be proud of.

TALK.START.PARA: —And only under us.
—That is quite correct. It has been achieved only under us, as the honourable member for Charlton says. That is significant. We have set in place a comprehensive package of economic management.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of privatisation was raised by those opposite. The honourable member for Charlton has spoken about the question of public infrastructure and private infrastructure. It seems to me that one of the issues that has to be addressed in this debate is the fact that there are some criteria for public ownership. For those who are employed in public enterprises and for those who depend upon their services, I say as a Government member that there are three dominant criteria for public ownership of an enterprise. If that enterprise serves areas of specific need-if, for instance, there is a welfare benefit to be achieved, such as the supply of funds for housing at a lower cost than can be provided by the market-place-that is one reason why we might require public activity. That is a very important area. With regard to the terminating building societies, for example, it is an important area for the delivery of services that we could not expect the private sector to deliver, because there is only a welfare reason, not a market-induced reason, for delivering them. That is the first important criterion.

The second criterion is the need for competition in a market-place where, if only private activity is taking place, there may not be effective competition. Historically in Australia, publicly owned enterprises have generated competition for privately owned enterprises. Due to the economies of scale, as the honourable member for Charlton knows, as a distinguished economist and author of texts, there are times when, because of the size of the market-place, particularly in an economy the size of Australia's--

TALK.START.PARA: —All his books are good books.

—That is quite correct. I thank the honourable member for Franklin, who himself is a devoted reader. They are all good books. It is important to emphasise that, where there is a smaller economic capacity, the market-place would very often tend toward an inefficient monopoly if there were not scope for public sector activity to provide some competition. We have seen that with the airlines. The Government is recognising the need to open up that over-regulated market-place. That is the second criterion, which I think those opposite tend to gloss over.

SPEECH.PARA: The third area, which is quite significant, is that of cross-subsidisation. Cross-subsidisation has been very important to the ability of Telecom Australia, for example, to deliver services to those in need. In provincial areas such as that represented by the honourable member for Charlton and in outer urban areas such as the outer metropolitan area of Perth-Gidgegannup, for example-where the connection fee for a telephone may be as high as $2,000 based on market charges, because of the element of cross-subsidisation it is possible for a corporate organisation such as Telecom to subsidise those un- economic activities using revenue transferred from other areas of its operations. We regard that as a very important activity. Those opposite, in their debate about privatisation, have tended to expose their rural constituencies. If their arguments were to be put up to their rural constituencies they would find themselves facing some very high charges. We do not think that is very attractive or something that we ought to pursue.

We on this side believe that the criteria I have listed for public ownership are very important. I reiterate them: first, that services are provided to those in need; secondly that an element of competition needs to be introduced into the market-place; and, thirdly, that an element of cross-subsidisation is required. The Labor Government and the Australian Labor Party have had a longer term interest in this matter and it is important to the debate that is currently taking place in the community.

The honourable member for Kooyong mentioned the question of tax collections. The honourable member for Charlton referred very accurately to the reduced public sector borrowing requirement under this Government and previous Hawke governments. It has been pointed out by those opposite that tax collections have gone up. It needs to be emphasised that we are collecting taxes from areas that previously were untaxed. Secondly, when we increase employment, as this Government has, we collect tax from people who have previously been unemployed-and that has happened. Thirdly, with the general level of economic activity increasing-and we have achieved economic growth in our time in office-it stands to reason that tax collections will increase. We are collecting from activities that were previously static or, as was certainly the case in the 1982 calendar year, declining. I refer to the massive unemployment created under the then Fraser-Howard stewardship.

We have seen a regeneration of economic activity leading to high levels of employment and high levels of production. It follows that we will have higher levels of taxation, because we have a wider productive base. The other thing to observe is that we have increased the efficiency of the tax system. We are collecting from areas which were previously left untaxed. If members of the Opposition want to open up that area for debate, we on this side, including the honourable member for Charlton and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), will be more than happy to accommodate them, because we recognise what we have done for the revenue side of government activity.

I conclude by saying, as the honourable member for Charlton said, that this levy imposes a charge but does so in such a way as to take account of the market-place. It also takes account of the market-place perception of what is happening in terms of public borrowings. The market-place does not make a distinction between borrowings in which there is an explicit guarantee and those in which there is an implicit guarantee. It sees a Commonwealth semi-government authority as having the authority of the Commonwealth behind it.

I interpolate that I think the Western Australian Government has acted prudently with respect to the guarantees it has provided in the Rothwells Ltd situation. It was a serious situation and the market-place recognised that. I think the private sector, in the funds it provided to Rothwells, also recognised that, and Premier Burke and his Cabinet have acted prudently and sensibly in responding to what clearly was a serious circumstance for the financial community in Western Australia and across Australia generally. It is important to observe that it took a Labor Government, with its responsibility for the wider community, to do that. The history of Australian economic activity shows that it is often the Labor governments that take the tough decisions, and take them responsibly. History treats us very favourably in that respect because people come to understand that we have always honoured our responsibility in this area. I am pleased to support the remarks of the honourable member for Charlton and the honourable member for Macarthur. I believe that these two Bills introduce some sensible reform into our activities in the market-place. They form part of the wider picture of responsible economic management by this Government and I am pleased to commend them to the House.

As the member for Canberra, with its substantial service population, I have naturally been aware of the significance of housing to the quality of service life. Since assuming my portfolio responsibilities, I have been able to address a number of aspects of the housing situation which do concern members of the Defence Force. I have, for example, asked the Interim Defence Housing Board to give high priority to the establishment of a responsive maintenance program. In the longer term, however, it is the establishment of the Defence Housing Authority which demonstrates the Government's commitment in this vital area. Establishment of the Authority is the purpose of this Bill.

The Bill is substantially the same as the Bill that was introduced into the House by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on 18 March 1987. The earlier Bill was passed by the House and introduced into the Senate but lapsed with the dissolution of the last Parliament. With regard to the earlier debate, I would like to note that a number of thoughtful comments about provisions of the legislation were made by Opposition speakers. While the terms of the Bill have not been changed, I do want to say that, if there is any necessity to review the legislation in the light of operating experience, those suggestions will be borne in mind.

In the earlier second reading speech, the Minister for Defence made it clear that the proposed legislation is the cornerstone of the Government's strategy to provide adequate accommodation for members of the Defence Force. In view of the pressure on parliamentary time during this period of sittings, I do not propose to repeat all the details of the previous speech. However, I would like to emphasise the following matters.

The Government has accepted a responsibility for housing its employees whose duty requires them to live where there is inadequate housing, or to live on the job. A further responsibility is to minimise disruption to family life caused by a requirement for frequent relocation of employees. But in addition to its proper responsibility as an employer the Government has a constitutional responsibility for the defence of the Commonwealth and its Territories. The discharge of that purpose of Government relies on the professional abilities of the men and women in the Defence Force. The proper housing of members of the Defence Force and their families is a critical element in maintaining a high level of morale and dedication to the important task of the Australian Defence Force.

The Defence Housing Authority is one of the most significant initiatives by this Government. It will reverse the trend of close to 40 years of neglect since the Second World War. There is no doubt that housing for the Defence Force in the years of neglect was allowed to fall below the standard for the rest of the community. The establishment of the Defence Housing Authority will remedy existing deficiencies and provide improved ongoing management of defence housing.

The Government believes that this task can only be carried out by a single dedicated organisation with the statutory powers that enable it to set its own course. It is also essential that the authority have the enterprise and expertise for its task, and that a guaranteed level of funds is committed to defence housing.

The necessary expertise, ranging from property development to social planning, will be ensured by the composition of the Authority's board. Its statutory independence will enable the greatest possible commercial freedom in operations, including the construction, improvement and disposal of housing. The Authority will have a guaranteed level of income by charging the Department of Defence full commercial rents for housing provided. I stress that this does not mean tenants will pay commercial rents, and their rentals will continue to be separately determined as a condition of service.

Although the Authority will be independent in its own task of providing housing, that will of course be within the framework of the Defence Force's operational needs. For example, the Authority would be expected to meet defence housing needs stemming from the Government's decisions to have a two-ocean navy and to re-locate 2nd Cavalry Regiment in Darwin.

The composition of the Authority has been carefully structured to ensure that the specialist skills required for its operations are directed towards defence needs. Four part time members-including the chairperson-will provide the necessary business expertise, as well as the professional skill needed to ensure that planning for housing takes account of the social needs of Defence Force members and their families. Four members, from the three Services and the Department, will represent the defence organisation. These members will also be in a position to present the social needs of service personnel and families, as well as the operational needs of the Defence Force.

The core of the Authority's task will be to meet the Government's commitment to improving the quality of defence housing up to the level of community standards. Within overall Budget priorities, the Government will aim to provide the Defence Housing Authority with funding, additional to its guaranteed income, needed to meet this objective. The magnitude of the task is recognised by the Government's firm proposal for an investment program totalling $750m over the next decade.

As defence housing problems had clearly become urgent, the Minister for Defence established an Interim Defence Housing Board late last year, on an administrative basis pending passage of legislation. That Board is headed by Mr John Graham, a former National President of the Housing Industry Association and director of the Sydney building firm of Civic Constructions Pty Ltd. Other external appointments include Dr Roy Gilbert, a former head of the Victorian Ministry of Housing, Mrs Valerie Pratt, a former personnel manager with CSR Ltd and now head of the Government's Affirmative Action Agency, and Mr Sam Salpietro, a Western Australian property developer and real estate agent. I propose to invite these members to be considered for appointment to the Authority when it is established.

Besides taking over ongoing housing programs in the Defence Department, the Interim Board is doing much of the preliminary work towards setting in place operating procedures and financial arrangements appropriate for the Authority. It has also gained a first hand knowledge of the housing stock and the dissatisfactions of service tenants.

The legislation contains all the standard provisions required for the operation of the Defence Housing Authority as a commercially oriented statutory authority. It has the capacity to do all things necessary to meet its objectives. It must of course be responsible to the Parliament through the Minister, who has powers of approval and direction consistent with ensuring observance of general government policies, adherence to its charter, and conformity to public standards of propriety and probity.
In addition to the matters that I have already mentioned, I would emphasise the following elements of the legislation:
The Authority is to meet housing requirements determined by the Minister;
There will be a corporate plan, including a financial plan, to be approved by the Minister;

The Authority is not subject to Commonwealth and State Government taxes unless that is provided for by the regulations. However, existing policy of making grants to local governments in lieu of rates will be continued;

The Minister is enabled to transfer defence housing and land to the Authority and these assets, together with any accumulated reserves and money appropriated by the Parliament, will form the Authority's capital; and
The Managing Director will be appointed by the Authority and will hold office at its pleasure.

I turn now to the financial impact of the Bill. At the outset I wish to repeat the assurance that provision of housing will continue to be regarded as a condition of service. Rent levels to be charged individual service tenants will be a matter for separate decision by the Government. A detailed statement of the financial impact of the Bill is set out in the accompanying explanatory memorandum. In summary, there will be an additional recurrent Budget outlay of $39m-the difference between the $126m that the Authority will charge the Commonwealth for rent and the $87m in present outlays that the Authority will pay instead of the Commonwealth. In addition, the Authority will retain revenue from the disposal of surplus housing. In 1986-87 this was about $5m. The Authority will use its profits for capital acquisition and improvements so demands for capital from the Budget-$65.8m in 1986-87-will be reduced. However, there will be supplementation from annual Budgets to meet the Government commitment of $750m over the next decade to upgrade the defence housing stock.

As the purpose of this Bill is to overcome one of the more serious areas of difficulty facing members of the Defence Force and their families, I am confident that it will have support from both sides of the House. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
