SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Defence Housing Authority Bill, which I note enjoys a degree of bipartisan support in this place. The Bill is substantially the same as the Bill which was passed through this place earlier this year, in March. We are debating this Bill again because of the double dissolution before the election on 11 July. The Bill is a little different this time and its presentation in this House is a little different because it is being handled today by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), the first female Minister we have had in this House since Dame Enid Lyons many years ago. So it is in that sense an historic piece of legislation. I congratulate the Minister on the way in which she has put this Bill before the House and on her achievements to date in her portfolio. This Bill establishes a Defence Housing Authority and the Government hopes that by establishing this Authority and the commitment to funding levels which will be provided over the next decade we can put an end to what has been 40 years of neglect, of haphazard arrangements, in relation to Defence Force housing. We believe, as a Government, that defence housing is extremely important. It is crucial to the conditions of service and to the morale of so many of our defence personnel who serve in all sorts of areas around Australia. Defence housing has a very high priority with this Government, a point which I will come back to a little later in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a few general comments about the work of this Defence Housing Authority and then to make a few criticisms of the contributions we just heard from the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who is the Opposition defence spokesperson. As I said, this Bill establishes the Defence Housing Authority, the function of which will be to provide suitable housing for members of the Australian Defence Force and their families in order to meet the Australian Defence Force's operational requirements. The Authority is designed to bring the necessary forms of expertise and the operating freedom to manage and to improve the defence housing stock. The governing Board of the Authority is to be of nine persons, four of whom are to be selected for their knowledge of housing operations. They will be part-time members and the managing director of the Authority will be a full-time statutory office holder and also a member of the Board. The Authority will assume control of defence housing stock. That is obviously a key provision of this Bill. Under this legislation the Authority will also be guaranteed a level of income. It is authorised to charge the defence budget a rent which is set on a commercial basis for each house in stock. It can dispose of unwanted stock and it can keep any proceeds of disposal.

In addition, the Minister for Defence has committed the Government to ensuring that the Authority has available some $750m for capital expenditure over the first decade of its operations. In anyone's language, that is an extremely significant capital contribution-and, again, that is a point that I will return to in a little while. Under this legislation the Authority is to be otherwise self-sustaining and must meet the cost of upkeep of the housing and its own administrative overheads. It will be charged for services provided by other agencies of government as in the case, for example, of any services provided by the construction authority in the Department of Administrative Services.

The Authority is also free to select any preferred strategy for achieving its objectives and does not have to use government agencies. It can build new houses, buy existing homes, form a company, enter into joint ventures and, with the approval of the Minister, can participate in other partnerships, and so on. So the Authority has a wide brief in which it can operate out there in the market-place to do the best it can in terms of providing housing for the Australian defence forces. The operating arrangements for the Authority have been developed in accordance with the Government's published policy guidelines for government business enterprises, which were released for comment in June last year. Finally, the Authority is required to prepare and update annually a corporate plan which sets out its objectives in the immediate future, along with the strategies and policies to achieve those objectives. So it must also produce a financial plan with specific performance indicators. That is a general run-down of the framework, purpose and nature of the Authority which is being established by this legislation.

The honourable member for McPherson, in his contribution in this House only a few moments ago, made a number of claims and allegations about the Government's overall defence policy and its record in defence and made some specific allegations about our record in respect of defence housing. I will spend a few minutes answering some of those claims. The honourable member for McPherson claimed that the state of the existing housing stock for defence personnel is in pretty poor shape generally. We agree, but much of the present defence housing stock has been provided over successive years, and for many years under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA). So it is stock which is made available to defence, but its ownership and hence the responsibility for its upkeep remain with the States. Clearly there have been problems in relation to the management of repairs and maintenance of those properties. Indeed, they have been a pervasive source of dissatisfaction among defence force tenants and it is because of the cumbersome arrangement, if you like, between ownership and control, management and use as between the States and the Commonwealth.

In response to an approach from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Commonwealth-State Relations (Mr Lionel Bowen), all State Premiers have agreed to enter into a renegotiation of the agreements governing defence housing. These negotiations are expected to get under way in about two months. I repeat: much of the housing stock is unsatisfactory and the causes that we identify include the problem of management and control in the past between the States and the Commonwealth, the stop-go levels of funding provided by previous conservative governments in the past, and a range of other matters. We hope that, as a result of the Premiers meeting in a month or two, the establishment of the Defence Force Housing Authority and the funding commitments given to the Authority over the next decade, many-if not all-of these problems will be remedied.

I will also comment on the claims by the honourable member for McPherson about this Government's overall record in terms of its defence policy. Every member on this side of the House is proud to stand here and defend the Government's record in terms of defence policy, programs and funding. It is a remarkable record in a fiscal environment in which we had to cut back spending from the prospective $9.6 billion deficit that we inherited on coming to government in 1983 to zero this year in the space of five Budgets and four mini-Budgets-so it has not been easy work. Even though we have done that, we have also maintained and improved most of the conditions in the defence forces. We have maintained real growth in most areas of capital expenditure, and we have ensured that in our defence industries there has been an enormous shift towards efficiency, self-sufficiency and exports. Those are all positive things right across the spectrum, however one wants to analyse our achievements and efforts in relation to defence.

In that extremely difficult fiscal environment we have managed to set basically realistic promises and realistic levels of spending for the future-and we have managed to keep to them. That contrasts extremely markedly with the Opposition's performance right through the 1970s when it was in government and brought down report after report promising future levels of spending for defence forces on unrealistically high and unachievable levels of real Budget spending. It could not meet those aims and that had disastrous effects right through the 1970s and early 1980s for the Australian defence forces, and it had disastrous effects on the morale of the defence forces.

We were party to a constant deferral of capital works because previous Liberal Defence Ministers simply could not get up the Budget increases to meet their required commitments. So we saw low morale, a constant deferral of capital works, a lack of real strategic planning, and a lack of work for our defence industries all around Australia. That meant that the degree of subsidy that had to be provided by the Commonwealth was much higher than was necessary and certainly much higher than is currently being provided in the more efficient defence industries that exist under this Government. That was the sort of policy framework that we inherited from the Opposition.

In regard to the Opposition's policy today, Opposition members come into this place and wax lyrical about what they would like to do for defence and they comment about the Government's programs and record in defence but, when they are asked to announce and enunciate their policy and state what they would do for the Australian defence forces for the next three years, five years or 10 years, there is an enormous vacuum, a total void and a big black hole because the Opposition simply does not have a policy and therefore cannot announce it. When the Opposition went into the last election only a few months ago, the only commitment that it had was to slash spending to finance massive tax cuts to people on big fat incomes. So it makes one wonder where the defence forces would be if the Government had changed on 11 July-where would they be in terms of manpower, in terms of defence housing and in terms of future capital works projects? My guess is that they would be very badly down the drain because defence spending, along with every other crucial item of government expenditure, would have been hacked to make way for massive tax cuts for the well-off.

I will conclude, because time is limited in this debate, by highlighting the Government's record in defence housing-another matter raised by the honourable member for McPherson. He criticised this Government's achievements, and I find that galling, to say the least, and inaccurate. In this year's Budget we have committed $75m for defence housing. In the five years of this Government's administration-from 1983-84 to 1987-88-capital expenditure on defence housing has totalled $260m. In the last five years of the previous Government capital expenditure was a mere $85m. So there has been five years of defence housing expenditure under this Government totalling $260m compared with $85m over five years by the Fraser Government. That is a large ratio of 3:1, which is an indication of the sort of relationship between the priority that this Government has given to this area and the priority of the previous Government.

If we look at it in terms of constant prices in real terms, which is the only fair and objective way to look at it, even in terms of real spending levels, we are spending in the ratio of $2 to $1 compared with what the Opposition spent on defence housing. If we look at what that produces on the ground in terms of tangible benefits for the Australian defence forces, which is what we are speaking about in this debate, it means that in the five years of this Government 2,580 dwellings have been completed compared with 1,335 during the last five years of the previous Government. Again, that is a ratio of around 2:1. So when Opposition members come in here and carp and whinge about the Government's defence housing policy, they ought to look at the facts. They ought to have the intestinal fortitude to go out to the Defence Force personnel and say, `Well, the real facts are these: the reality is that the Hawke Government has done a job in defence housing which is second to none. It is certainly twice as good as the job that we did'. The Opposition ought to commend the Hawke Government and hope that it keeps that priority, as I can say, in this debate, I know we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say, in response to the comments made by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), that the Opposition, throughout this important afternoon of debate on defence matters, including initiating a discussion of a matter of public importance, has stuck to the facts in relation to the attrition rate of our armed forces and has not used the rhetoric which the honourable member brought before the House in his comments on the Defence Housing Authority Bill 1987.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Firstly, I have been misrepresented. Secondly, the Bill before the House has nothing at all to do with attrition rates from the defence forces. With respect, even a person with the weirdest imagination could not claim that the Bill has anything to do with the attrition rate amongst personnel in the Australian defence forces.
—On that point of order--
—No argument is permitted on a point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the honourable member does not realise that housing is a key element in the morale of members of the armed forces, I have a much lesser opinion of his appreciation of defence matters and I regret that that might be so. Even the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table, has indicated previously her strong feeling that housing is very central to the morale of our Army, Navy and Air Force personnel and is therefore relevant to whether they are going to resign, extend, renew their terms, or apply for additional terms in the armed forces.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly support the amendment to the motion for the second reading, moved by my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and seconded by his neighbouring colleague, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). This in-principle second reading amendment puts this legislation in perspective. Many members on both sides of the House, especially members who represent large military complexes, have a great concern for the standard of service housing. The Latchford Barracks in the Albury-Wodonga military area is one of the largest inland military complexes in Australia. I know that the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron) and I, as well as others, have previously made strong representations in relation to this matter. When the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) visited Wodonga earlier this year, I showed him some of the housing which has caused so much concern.

I would like to take this opportunity to reflect on the fact that this is the first Bill to be brought before the House of Representatives by a lady Minister. I recognise that this is a milestone. We should remember, of course, that there have been previous instances in the Senate of legislation being introduced by lady Ministers. This Bill attracted very good debate when it came before the Parliament earlier this year. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel alluded to that debate in her earlier comments. I want to go back to that debate briefly and quote a comment that I gave to the House then which is as relevant today as it was on 28 April 1987. I want to quote what the august Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator John Button, had to say on 24 February this year. He said:
Families with young children and wage earners generally were worse off as a result of Hawke Government policies.
He also said:

But I concede that those families are probably worse off as other sections of the community are also probably worse off. I am sure that while some families are relatively worse off, families with young children . . .

He went on to make the comment that they were particularly subject to difficulties at that time. I want to highlight to the House that often young married members of the Army, Navy and Air Force with young families face the cost burdens associated with a situation which is greatly exacerbated when the standard of housing that is available to them is poor. For example, this winter a house in Wodonga had no hot water for 36 hours. This situation resulted in suffering and difficulty for the two young babies in that household. Incidentally, that house was occupied by an officer of the Australian Army. So this serious housing situation in the armed forces is not restricted just to privates, corporals or sergeants. It extends across all ranks. I hope genuinely that the Defence Housing Authority legislation will do something about this. I hope that the Defence Housing Authority will do something positive and that it will not be just another quango of government interested in creating a headquarters Taj Mahal which could turn into being something larger than necessary. In 1987 this Parliament should not be about setting up more instrumentalities and authorities unless there is specific genuine cause and unless the authorities so created can efficiently go about their tasks. That is why I submit strongly to the House that the Minister and the Government need to watch very closely the performance of the Defence Housing Authority. We need to ensure that it sticks to its task, that it achieves and that it does not drift down the path of so many government instrumentalities and not really solve the problem which we are addressing here this evening.

Not unrelated to the Defence Housing Authority legislation and the whole question of housing for our armed forces is the defence service home loans scheme area, which I know that the Minister, in conjunction with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), has pursued on a number of occasions. I just want to make passing reference to that scheme. The termination of the scheme, as we knew it, was announced by way of a Budget decision. After a lot of pressure from all sources, including the armed forces and the Opposition, and a further meeting, the Ministers jointly announced that there was to be backdown on that Budget decision and that applications would continue to be accepted under the existing defence service homes loan scheme until the details of the new scheme were worked out. We will be watching with a great deal of interest-as the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I will be especially watchful-to see that the new scheme does not short change the veteran or the retired soldiers, sailors or airmen who have a certain expectation arising from their contract of service with Her Majesty's Government. Veterans could well be short changed on leaving the armed forces as a result of the original proposal for a cash grant in lieu of a $25,000 loan. So I put it to the Minister that, in finalising the new defence service home loans scheme and in sticking to a very tight timetable which the Ministers set in saying that the new scheme would be in place by 1 January 1988, we will be watching to make sure that they do not in their alternative scheme of a cash non-repayable, non-taxable grant, short change the veteran and the serviceman, vis-a-vis the value of the existing $25,000 average 6.8 per cent loan scheme. If they do, I serve notice that, first, the rate of resignations from the armed forces will further increase, and secondly, there will be absolute animosity amongst ex-service personnel and veterans for what they will represent as being yet a further massive breach of commitment and contract by the Government in respect of the debt that is owed to so many of them.

There are just two other areas on which I shall touch briefly. The first concerns defence housing and the problems that are encountered in the administration of the defence service home loans scheme. Sadly, I have here the Vietnam medals of a private. I will not reveal his name to the House, but I will reveal it to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I will just use his initials-Mr P.G.R. He sent me his Vietnam medals this week and said, amongst other things, that he was returning these medals; he would like me to pass on the medals to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs because he had had enough, and he thanked the Government for nothing in terms of the service he gave this nation.

This is a sad case, and I am not prepared to publicise all the details because I would like to see the Minister genuinely review this person's problem. I hope that as a result of my raising the matter in this forum, the veteran might think again about handing in his medals, because those medals were an honour given by the Australian people, and it is a very big step to hand in one's medals as a form of protest. Nevertheless, it reflects the fact that Mr P.G.R. has reached such a stage of frustration. In the brief time that is available to me, I can inform the House that he is frustrated because, as a consequence of his defence service, including Vietnam service, he has been left with a severe asthma condition. He is on a special rate totally and permanently incapacitated pension. He lives in a dusty and difficult climatic section in south-west Sydney. On medical advice, he has applied for transfer to another climatic location in Queensland. Thus far, the Defence Service Homes Corporation has refused to approve the transfer of his home loan from a house in New South Wales to one in Queensland.

As this is a specific matter, I will not dwell on it. I raise it in a responsible way in the House and I will pass on the details to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I hope that he will order a review of this case. I will return Mr P.G.R.'s medals to him. If he still wants to hand them in, I will suggest that he sends them to the Minister directly. Perhaps we will be able to solve his case, which reflects the great concern over defence housing in general not only for current serving personnel but also for ex-service personnel and veterans. The issue is related to morale, the composition of our armed forces and the decision factor of whether people will renew their terms of service in the Army, Navy or Air Force. Of course they will be more inclined to renew and extend their terms of service if they have adequate housing. If they do not have adequate housing, that will be a contributing factor to their resignation.

This country has been taking its defence for granted for far too long. The time is fast approaching when Australia, as a nation, is likely to be caught with its pants down, and on a Sunday afternoon. Our region is not the stable, secure area that we have traditionally regarded it in the aftermath of World War II and the Korean and Vietnam wars. It is anything but that, when one looks at the detailed political composition of some of our neighbours and the attitudes of some elements in the governments of our neighbours. We need to be as vigilant today in the defence of our nation as our forefathers were in two great world wars and beyond. It is for those reasons that I ask the House to give special consideration to the Defence Housing Authority Bill and the amendment moved by the honourable member for McPherson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to see that you are in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker. Our paths often cross at neighbouring electorate functions, and I am pleased to see you in that august position.
—I thank the honourable member for his comments.

—As I rise to speak for the Defence Housing Authority Bill, it is rather a case of `once more with feeling' because the Bill has been through the House on a previous occasion. But it is important to raise a number of issues in relation to the Bill before it finally passes through the House. I begin by complimenting both the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) on their measured contributions to this debate. I note with approval that the honourable member for McPherson, who is the shadow Minister, said that the Opposition had little disagreement with the Bill and it was `a major step in the right direction'. I think that he was rather complimentary of the Government on introducing the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: However, he made a number of comments which I shall address quickly. The first was that the Government has shown a lack of urgency in bringing forward the Bill. My response to that is to remind the honourable member that the Government acted immediately to set up an interim Defence Housing Board, pending the passage of this legislation, and it was only because of the calling of the election that the legislation was not enacted substantially earlier in the year. I also support the call, which I understood the honourable member to make, for some broadening of the representation on the new Defence Housing Authority. As the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table, nodded earlier, I gather that she was prepared to consider the possibility at least of a representative of the National Consultative Group of Services Spouses serving on the board at some later stage. I believe that service spouses who are at the coal-face, if you like, of having to deal with defence housing are in an ideal position to be able to make a direct and effective contribution to the operation of the Authority.

The honourable member for McPherson also spoke of the need to act on the condition of single service accommodation. I agree with him, but I remind him that in the current financial year the Government is committing $60m to that very project. I was also reminded in the course of the debate, by the appearance of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) in the chamber, that when he was the Minister for Defence he and I visited housing at Holsworthy and in the Liverpool area. The former Minister reminded me that what we were confronted with on that first-time inspection for both of us was literally slum housing that was built as temporary accommodation around the end of World War II, and which was unbelievably cold and depressing accommodation. It was really little more than what we would regard as Third World accommodation and was not suitable for the defence forces in the 1980s. It is no doubt for that reason that the Opposition did not seek to blame this Government for what has been at least 40 years of neglect of defence housing. While the shadow Minister called for greater promptness in bringing the Bill before the House, I should indicate that throughout all those years of Liberal government, no action was taken to bring about what is now regarded by both sides of the House as a very worthwhile and constructive reform.

The honourable member for Farrer, in his contribution to the Bill, said that the Government needs to monitor the performance of the Authority. I agree with that. I think we would all agree that if we can improve the Authority we should do so. He also referred to the defence service home loans scheme. In that regard I am sure that most of my colleagues, including the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), who have an absolute commitment to the service personnel in their electorates, would share my concern that we ought to be encouraging the Government to make the right decision prior to 1 January that will give service personnel and veterans some real security and justice in relation to their defence service home loans. I hope that the Government will heed that very heartfelt call.

The reform before the House tonight is part of a package. It is part of a package and a strategy of this Government to improve substantially the conditions of Australian Defence Force personnel. The strategy includes the establishment of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, the establishment of the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service, the establishment of a first-ever Minister responsible for service personnel and the action of Government members in setting up the Government members defence force action committee.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I fully concur with the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson, who said, in the course of his contribution, that the Government's initiative was a major step in the right direction. It is great to hear the Opposition fully supporting the Government on such an important matter. This is a very important advance for the Australian defence forces, as my colleague the honourable member for Herbert, another staunch proponent of improved conditions for defence personnel, will soon inform the House.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just our view that the passage of the Defence Housing Authority Bill is an important step. The retiring Chief of the Defence Force, General Sir Phillip Bennett, wrote of his views about important matters concerning the Government's initiatives in this area. He was quoted in an article in the Army Fortnightly on 16 April as saying:

Establishment of a Defence Housing Authority will benefit many of . . . the soldiers as the standard of housing and the way that the housing stock is administered improve. Although the total impact of the Housing Authority may take some time to become apparent, in the shorter term the improvement in the timeliness and standard of maintenance will quickly become evident.

I fully agree with what General Sir Phillip Bennett said on that occasion. As I have indicated, this Bill forms part of a package of initiatives and a strategy of the Government to advance the conditions of service personnel and their families, which have also included the establishment of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Service, the establishment for the first time of the position of Minister for Defence Science and Personnel-who is directly responsible to the Parliament for service personnel issues-and, of course, the Government back bench initiative of the establishment of a Government members defence force action committee.

I speak in the course of this debate not just as a local member representing the electorate of Hughes, in which Holsworthy is located, but also as the convenor of that Government members defence force action committee. The members compliment the Government for this initiative. We place on record our fondest hope that the new Minister will carry on the work of Minister Beazley in advancing the conditions of defence personnel.

The Bill that is before the House forms part of a three-pronged approach to improving defence housing: firstly, that we give a guaranteed level of funds; secondly, that we bring in outside expertise and business acumen for the task; and, thirdly, that we establish a single organisation dedicated to the management of defence housing and streamlining of functions. The authority will have, as I said, a guaranteed level of income by charging the Department of Defence full commercial rents for the housing provided. As the Minister said in her second reading speech, this does not mean that tenants will pay commercial rents and that their rentals will continue to be separately determined as a condition of service. It is not the view of this Government that service personnel ought to be charged market rents. It is not our view, as has been put by the Opposition through the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), that we ought to sell defence housing to private interests. We in the Government know that the effect of that massive sell-off would be to send rents for defence families through the roof. They simply could not afford to pay those market rents; nor should they, as the provision of adequate housing ought properly to be seen, I believe, as a condition of service.

The new Authority will be free to select its own strategy for achieving its objectives. It does not have to use Government agencies. It can build new houses, buy existing homes, form companies, enter into joint ventures and participate in partnerships. The arrangements for the Authority have been developed in accordance with the Government's published policy guidelines for Government business enterprises. The Authority will be required to prepare and update annually a corporate plan which sets out the objectives in its immediate future and the strategies and policies to achieve those objectives.

I think it is important that, in the course of this debate, I make brief reference to what I consider to be one of the major issues confronting the new Authority. That concerns the present state of Defence Force housing which has been provided under successive Commonwealth- State Housing Agreements. That housing stock is made available to Defence, but ownership, and hence responsibility for its upkeep, remains with the States. The difficulties with repairs and maintenance have been the most pervasive source of dissatisfaction among Defence Force tenants.

If I relate to the House a small story which brought home to me the incredible frustration that defence families have, I think honourable members will have a better understanding of the problem. In the course of this year I was able to organise a public meeting in my electorate. The guest speaker was the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). In the course of that meeting, while introducing the Minister, I had cause to relate that, as a local member of parliament, I was available to service my constituents on a range of matters. Not only was I involved in taking up a range of national issues; I was involved in quite routine day to day matters. I even said that occasionally people contacted me about blocked drains. That night, after attending another function and getting home at 11 o'clock, sure enough, the telephone rang and my wife answered it. It was someone from Holsworthy who, for two days, had been living in a house-her husband was involved in exercises in north Queensland-with three children and could not use any of the household facilities because of blocked drains. Fortunately, I was able to use my good offices as a member of parliament, make contact with the authorities and get some immediate action.

There are often tremendous problems with Defence Force housing which do not easily enable service spouses-who, as I have said, are often in the front line and are directly responsible for their families while their husbands are away-to have immediate repairs done in these cases. I am pleased to note that, in response to an approach from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Commonwealth-State Relations (Mr Lionel Bowen), all Premiers of the States have agreed to enter into a renegotiation of the agreements governing defence housing. These negotiations are expected to get under way quite soon. The Government has acknowledged that many of the problems relating to defence housing need to be resolved. The causes that we identify as problems include the stop-go funding for housing in the past and, as I have said, the divided control of housing matters across the Services and other departments. I hope that the establishment of the Defence Housing Authority will do a great deal to overcome these problems.

In conclusion, I place on record, as I have already done, that it is my view that the shadow Minister made a valuable contribution to this debate. I welcome his acknowledgment that this is an important step on the part of the Government. I commend the suggestion that a member of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses ought to be included as a member of the Authority. I also place on record that it is a matter of great regret to me that this initiative was not undertaken a long time ago. It is the sort of initiative that should have been undertaken, not a year ago, not two years ago, but 20 years ago. It is because of that neglect by successive governments that we now have a problem that means that so much more by way of resources and new programs is needed in order to overcome the neglect that has occurred over that very long period. I welcome the passage of the Bill and commend it to the House. I compliment the Minister for what I believe is an important start to her new and very significant portfolio responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Housing Authority Bill 1987 reminds me of the Punch cartoon of 1895 which depicted a curate breakfasting with his bishop. `I am afraid you've got a bad egg, Mr Jones.', said the obviously concerned bishop in response to the equally obvious look of dismay on the face of the curate. `Oh, no, my Lord.', replied the curate, endeavouring to adopt a constructive and positive attitude to the disaster confronting him in his eggcup: `I assure you parts of it are excellent'. Like the curate's egg, this Bill is good in parts.

SPEECH.PARA: And like the curate, those on this side of the House are endeavouring to adopt a positive and constructive attitude to this proposed legislation. After all, when one is hungry an egg that is good in parts is substantially better than no egg at all. When one is forced to live in some of the most appalling substandard accommodation provided by an employer in Australia today-and I refer, of course, to those structures euphemistically called `homes' or `houses' by our Department of Defence-a Bill that offers us some hope for improvement is better than nothing.

Whilst we are not opposing the passage or provisions of this Bill, we are concerned that the Government should recognise and acknowledge the fact that the provision of decent housing is a basic but nonetheless critically important factor in conditions of service for our Defence Force personnel. We are talking about men and women and their families who are already often making substantial personal sacrifices in the service of their country. That some of them should also be called upon to cope with living under the most intolerable and disgraceful conditions is simply expecting too much. This is amply demonstrated by the current catastrophic wastage rates which are depleting the ranks of our defence forces at all levels.

A major factor in this alarming and increasing exodus from the Services is dissatisfaction with substandard housing. This excessive turnover in skilled service men and women not only jeopardises the security of this nation but also costs Australian taxpayers literally hundreds of millions of dollars in additional and unnecessary costs associated with retirement, recruitment and retraining of defence personnel. This concern is illustrated in our proposed amendment, as is our regret that the Government has failed to introduce adequate and practical measures to assist Defence Force personnel to purchase privately built homes. This is a practical initiative which so far has been ignored by the Government but which, if taken up and acted upon, would greatly assist in solving the current defence housing problems whilst at the same time providing a much needed lift to the morale of our service men and women and their spouses and families.

During my 25 years of service in the Royal Air Force I experienced first-hand many of the traumas, and even the horrors of sub-standard Defence Force housing. I watched my wife coping with four small children in living quarters which were so bad as to be almost unbelievable. We laugh about it now but at the time we almost cried. During those 25 years we endured-and I use the word advisedly-23 different changes of residential address. That is not to say that we did not enjoy service life; we loved it and we thrived on it. Nor does it mean that we were always confronted with the prospect of living in poor accommodation; we were not.

When one is required to lead what might best be described as a gypsy existence, sometimes it can be a lot of fun and very exciting; sometimes it can be most daunting. But the stresses and strains, both physical and emotional, of continually having to pack up home and family and move on are always substantial, always challenging. They are exacerbated when one arrives at one's latest destination only to find that the tin hut in the corner is, in fact, one's new home and will be home until one is eventually posted elsewhere.

This happened to me when I was sent to a little known RAAF base at Snake Creek, some 72 miles south of Darwin. I can only surmise as to why I was sent there, but if it was little known when I arrived it was well known-or at least it had a wider reputation-by the time I left. I was accompanied on this expedition into the unknown-for that is what it was-by my wife Maggie and our two children, who at the time were both under two years of age. With your indulgence, Madam Speaker, I digress here just for a moment to record the fact that when we departed from Snake Creek some three years later, we were the proud parents of four children under five. The area had a lot of things going for it but television was not one of them.

For the duration of our posting to Snake Creek Maggie and I and our family called that hut home. It had no internal walls, no internal plumbing, no floor coverings, unless one counts the concrete, and the only cooking facility was a camp stove. It was necessary to boil the bore water before using it. There were no proper laundry facilities. Despite the oppressive climate there were no cooling facilities. Although our tin hut was by any definition exceedingly humble, the limited protection afforded by its corrugated iron roof and walls was much in demand. We had little option but to share our home with the local native fauna including lizards, scorpions, foot-long centipedes and not forgetting the bats. Fortunately, the snakes preferred to dwell within the precincts of the outside toilet-we believed it was the toilet. In the absence of any obvious alternative that is what we used it for. The snakes used it as a base for their terrorist activities.

Having lived under these conditions, I am fully aware of, and can readily appreciate, the current level of despondency and despair in regard to Defence Force housing that is now so evident amongst our service men and women and their families. We have only to refer to Appendix B of the document, researched and complied by Ms Sue Hamilton-it is an excellent document-entitled Supporting Service Families-A Report on the main problems facing spouses of Australian Defence Force personnel, and some recommended solutions. Appendix B of this report lists 23 items most frequently identified as desirable, but not consistently available, in married quarters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they all implemented?

—They are not quite implemented. These 23 items include such basic necessities as floor treatments appropriate to the particular area; adequate security equipment-nothing sophisticated-such as deadlocks, security doors and, in some areas, window locks. The list also includes curtain rods, fly screens, insulation, telephone sockets. Safety measures recommended include fences to keep toddlers from wandering, high cupboards or shelves for the storage of poisons, rails on high verandahs, non-slip surfaces on outside steps. Television antennae, exhaust fans in kitchens and bathrooms-we are really into the up-market luxury items here are we not?-adequate cupboard space, separate lavatories . . . the list goes on. They are all basic, if not essential, every day commodities which are so universally lacking in existing Defence Force housing that they qualify for inclusion on a list of frequently identified items which are not consistently available. It is just not good enough for this Government, which has now been in power since 1983 as the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) so readily recognises. He should have particular cognisance of this debate for within his electorate lies the very large Army establishment at Puckapunyal.
—You want to see the new houses we are building there.

—We wait impatiently to see them. The Hamilton report also canvasses other sometimes relatively minor, but nonetheless significant problems confronting occupants of service housing. One important area is the difficulty resulting from poor maintenance standards and the frustrations involved in trying to get necessary repairs carried out in an acceptable manner and within a reasonable time. Another is the offhanded attitude sometimes displayed by housing staff when dealing with their tenants. Yet another is the shortage of married quarters with four or more bedrooms. There are also difficulties associated with the tendency for offbase accommodation to be located in socially disadvantaged areas, and the consequent problems with maintaining security and obtaining insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: If the proposed Defence Housing Authority can address these matters along with its other significant responsibilities and arrive at some practical and effective solutions, it will certainly provide a valuable and much needed support service for our badly neglected service men and women and their disillusioned spouses and families.

The capacity of the Authority to tackle its enormous and complex task, to unscramble the well scrambled egg, is dependent upon the resources available to it. Without adequate funding, it cannot hope to be successful and, unfortunately, there appears to be some doubt as to how adequate its funding will be. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), in his initial Press release on 30 January 1987 announcing the proposed establishment of the Defence Housing Authority, stated:
An expanded funding program of more than $750m during the next decade is to be used to bring the current stock of houses up to standard.
Later in the same Press release, he said:
Within overall Budget priorities the Government will aim to provide the Defence Housing Authority with funding, additional to its guaranteed income, needed to meet this objective.
Later again he referred to the massive task confronting the Authority and outlined some of its priorities. Again I quote:
Of the 22,000 houses currently managed by Defence, the worst 6,000 will be progressively replaced and other houses of inadequate standard will be refurbished.

Although the Minister has consistently maintained a hedging the bets attitude in regard to the availability of adequate funding, his statements implying that the Authority will be able to direct at least some of the Government provided $750m towards refurbishing and upgrading existing housing stocks do not entirely accord with subsequent statements on how this money may be spent. First, let us further examine the issue of the availability of adequate funding. In his ministerial statement when presenting the Defence of Australia policy information paper, the Minister referred to the so-called Government commitment to spend $750m on improving housing in the following terms:
We plan to spend $750m over the next 10 years . . .

Honourable members on both sides of the House will be well aware of the old saying about the best laid plans. He reinforced the element of uncertainty in regard to this commitment in his second reading speech delivered on 18 March, during the original debate on the Defence Housing Authority Bill when he said:
Within overall Budget priorities, the Government will aim to provide the Defence Housing Authority with funding, additional to its guaranteed income, needed to meet this objective.

This statement was paraphrased slightly by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) representing the Minister for Defence, when this Bill was reintroduced into the Senate on 15 September 1987. Senator Button's version was:
Within overall Budget priorities, it is the Government's intention to have $750m committed to defence housing capital outlays over the next decade.

What we have here is a lot of good intentions and no firm, unequivocal commitments. We can only hope that, in this instance at least, the Governments's aim is on target and its plans come to fruition.

In regard to the second rather grey area-that of how the money may actually be used-the Minister's original grand statements about upgrading existing stocks have been somewhat modified. The White Paper released in March 1987 clearly states on page 97, under item 7.27-Defence housing:
Some $750m will be spent on new housing over the next 10 years.
This statement was repeated by the Minister in his ministerial statement on 19 March 1987 when he said:
We plan to spend $750m over the next 10 years on new housing for the Defence Force.

These two significant references to new housing are in apparent conflict with earlier statements about upgrading existing housing-that is, unless the Minister has apprenticed himself to Aladdin and, with a couple of judicious rubs, can convert old houses to new houses. But I doubt whether even his talents extend that far. A new house is a new house. An upgraded house is an existing house which has been refurbished. The two are quite different.

It would be nice to know just what the Minister intends in regard to how the $750m is to be spent. This is particularly important when the proposal to relocate the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to Darwin, the FA18 squadron's relocation to Tindal and the decisions to base half the fleet at HMAS Stirling in Western Australia are taken in account. All these new bases will need new housing. How much of the $750m will that absorb? How much will be left to spend on the 13,147 sub-standard houses that currently exist within the present stock of 22,941 married quarters? What about the 6,000 of these 13,000 plus sub-standard houses that cannot be saved? How much will be left for the replacement of these homes? What about the estimated 10,000 married members of the defence services who currently cannot be accommodated at all from service housing stocks? Suddenly the $750m does not seem very generous. Over 10 years, it is ludicrous, especially when it is not even guaranteed.

There are two other aspects that I would like briefly to mention. The first is rents. Secondly, I regret that there is no room on the Board of the Authority for a representative from the non-commissioned ranks and/or service spouses-for example, from the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses-who may not have the required expertise but would certainly be in a position to speak with the voice of experience when it came to identifying the problems and possible solutions, which will be in the field of responsibility of the new Authority.

This very matter was the subject of personal representations to the Minister and senior officers of the Department of Defence by members of the Armed Forces Federation of Australia when this legislation was first mooted. That no action has been taken on their very valid and appropriate suggestion is, I believe, a sad reflection on the attitude of this Government towards the lower ranks and the spouses of Defence Force personnel. Both these groups have made, and continue to make, a major contribution to all aspects of service life and its associated responsibilities. They share the challenges, and often are required to bear the brunt of many of the sacrifices that must be made in the course of duty. Even though they have been passed over in regard to any formal recognition of their ability to make a constructive contribution to decisions which are very likely to have considerable impact on themselves, their families and their whole way of life and standard of living, it is to be hoped that the members of the Board of the Authority will make every effort to consult closely and frequently with spouse groups and lower ranks so that, to paraphrase the words of John Milton, those who only stand and wait may also have an opportunity to serve.

I appreciate the difficulties and understand the challenges that are posed by inadequate Defence Force housing. I have shared them. I sympathise with those currently serving members of our defence forces and their families who are at present forced to live in sub-standard accommodation, and I do not blame them for considering alternative employment options as a solution to their ongoing housing problems. But, perhaps more importantly, I know that the existing deplorable housing conditions can and must be improved. I join with my coalition colleagues in their efforts and determination to ensure that the necessary upgrading takes place.

The Bill we are debating here tonight is but a small first step. It is a rather faltering step, as I have illustrated, but at least it is something and, as I said earlier, something-anything-is better than nothing at all. This Government has a long overdue responsibility to remedy the current unacceptable situation. It must do so by treating this as a matter of the utmost urgency; by according it a high priority and by ensuring that the Defence Housing Authority has the necessary Government support and assistance to complete the important work that it has been given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Housing Authority Bill is indeed a very welcome Bill. This is the second time this vital piece of legislation has come before the House. It is quite possible that one of the factors contributing to the current personnel separations problem could be housing. This Government will admit that. The most frequent area of complaint and a source of great frustration for the people I consulted was the poor standard of maintenance in service housing, particularly in that leased from various State housing authorities. Tenants complained of delays in carrying out maintenance and of the poor quality of work and materials when maintenance was done, resulting in rapid deterioration.

I am of course aware, that the whole issue of service housing has been an area of great concern recently and that initiatives have now been put in place with the intention of improving the quality and management of the housing stock.

That guarantee of commitment was not present in the past when conservative governments were in office.

The Authority is designed to bring the necessary forms of expertise and the operating freedom, to manage and to improve the defence housing stock. Members of the Board also made an inspection of a number of defence facilities to familiarise themselves with housing conditions. The external members include Mr John Graham as Chairman-Mr Graham is Managing Director of Civic Constructions Pty Ltd, Sydney-Dr Roy Gilbert, former Head of the Ministry of Housing, Victoria; Mrs Valerie Pratt, now head of the Affirmative Action Agency, but formerly a personnel manager for CSR Ltd, and Mr Sam Salpietro, a real estate developer in Western Australia, and adviser on housing to the State Govenrment. Mr William Kirkby-Jones has been selected as Managing Director of the Authority. All these people, together with Defence Force and departmental officers, bring to the Defence Housing Authority a wide range of expertise to ensure its successful operation, in accordance with sound commercial practice.

Incorporated in the legislation is the requirement for the Authority to prepare and update annually, a corporate plan which will include forcasts of receipts and expenditure and financial targets for profit, rate of return and dividend approved by the Minister. How often do we sit in this House and hear ideas about corporate planning from that side of the House whose members are totally bereft of any progressive ideas? This corporate plan will provide a strategy for sound financial management. The words `sound financial management' probably sound foreign to members opposite.

The Authority will also be required to earn a reasonable rate of return on its assets and maintain the Commonwealth's level of equity. While the Authority will receive commercial rents for properties which will guarantee a level of income, it is important to note that Defence Force tenants, as a condition of service will continue to pay subsidised rents, which the Government will continue to determine. The Authority is free to select any preferred strategy for achieving its objectives. It can build new houses, buy existing homes, form a company, enter into joint ventures, participate in partnerships and so on. In the latter instances, prior approval is needed.

With the approval of the Treasurer, the Authority has the power to borrow. The establishment of the Defence Housing Authority heralds a new era. Gone are the days of stop and go funding for defence housing; gone are the days when defence housing was a low priority; gone are the days of inefficient and costly maintenance work. Our service families can look forward with confidence to having adequate housing standards geared to today's community expectations. Changes in living standards will not happen overnight, but at long last positive steps have been taken that will guarantee changes will be made. The guarantee is that those changes will be improvements. God, how our defence force personnel need attention and improved housing conditions after the years of neglect when the mob on the opposite side were on this side of the House. This Government has honoured its commitment to improved housing conditions for service families. I congratulate the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). I am sure that those opposite who feel genuinely about the living conditions of our defence force personnel will join me in commending this Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been here for only three months.

—I am talking about the full Minister for Defence. Part of that action was the drafting of this legislation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Defence Housing Authority Bill is similar to the Defence Housing Authority Bill that was introduced into this House by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on 18 March 1987. I now add a few observations on the Defence Housing Authority to be established by clause 4 of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members who take a keen interest in conditions of service for defence personnel would know that there would not have been an urgent need for the establishment of a Defence Housing Authority and the expenditure of $750m over the next decade on the provision of housing for defence personnel if the Fraser Government had not contemptuously broken a number of pledges which it made to members of the Australian Defence Force on this issue. Under the previous Liberal-National Party Government, the provision of housing for defence personnel under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement as a proportion of expenditure on defence dropped dramatically. From 1.8 per cent of total expenditure in 1975-76-the last financial year of the Whitlam Labor Government-this component of expenditure fell to less than 0.2 per cent under the Liberal-National Party Government in 1982-83. Eight million dollars was committed in 1982-83 under the Fraser Government for housing of defence personnel compared with $34m for defence housing under Labor in 1975-76. In real terms the movement between 1975-76 and 1982-83 represented a decline in the budget sub-division of 88 per cent when deflated by the implicit price deflator for final consumption-government.

In respect of housing acceptances, in 1975-76, the year of the last Whitlam Labor Budget, 938 houses were accepted by the Department of Defence. The following year, under the Fraser Government, 582 houses were accepted for defence personnel and in 1979-80 only 75 houses were accepted by the Department of Defence.

The 1976 defence White Paper noted there was a shortage of married quarters in most areas. To begin to meet the requirement for accommodation of adequate standard, the White Paper noted an objective to obtain a further 3,200 houses by the early 1980s. However, during the period 1976 to 1981 a little more than half of the stated objective of 3,200 houses had been accomplished: in fact, only 1,664 houses had been accepted during that period. So by 1983 when the Hawke Government was elected, the housing situation was as bad as that which the White Paper had indicated would be improved by the early 1980s and was assessed as some 3,000 houses short of the actual demand.

As in many other areas under the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government, the defence housing program for service personnel had seemingly stood still. What a woeful record the Liberal-National Party had on defence matters. Not only did the Liberal-National Party Government scrimp on money for adequate defence housing, but also in 1982 the Liberal-National Party Government froze the pay of defence personnel. Under the Liberal-National Party Fraser Government, Australia's defence personnel were underpaid, underequipped, underhoused, taken for granted and generally ignored. The Liberal-National Party Government never bothered to instigate an inquiry into the conditions of defence service families of the kind initiated by the Hawke Government such as that which resulted in the Hamilton report, Supporting Service Families. Mrs Hamilton concluded as a result of her investigations that the poor standard of defence housing-particularly poor maintenance-was a significant contributor to low family morale in the Services. There is no excuse for poor maintenance of defence housing.

I now refer to the achievements of the Hawke Government in the provision of good standard housing for defence personnel. In 1983-84, the first fiscal year of the Hawke Government, actual capital expenditure on defence housing amounted to $36.8m, for 440 completions of housing accepted by the Department of Defence. In 1984-85, $38.5m was spent, for 330 houses accepted by the Department of Defence; in 1985-86, $54m for 520 houses accepted by the Department of Defence; in 1986-87, $55.2m for 360 houses accepted by the Department of Defence; and this year, 1987-88, $75m for an estimated 930 houses to be accepted by the Department of Defence. That tells much about the achievements of the Hawke Government, an authentic Australian government, in the less than five years in which it has been the Government of this country. Compare the $8m spent by the Fraser Government with the $75m spent by the Hawke Government this year.

There is no government in the history of Australia that has been more supportive of promoting defence, an adequate Defence Force for the protection of Australia and its people, than the Hawke Government. The Hawke Government has spent more money for defence purposes than any other government in Australia's history. It is spending more money for defence purposes this financial year than has been spent on defence at any time in Australia's history.

Its achievements in re-equipping and re-arming the Australian Defence Force are unmatched by any previous government. It has, for the first time, commenced the urgent and overdue deployment of Australia's defence forces to the northern areas of Australia. It has decided to rebuild the Royal Australian Navy, to equip it with adequate ships and other materiel to provide a two-ocean Navy. SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important that as members of the Parliament we stop for a minute and consider our responsibility to the Australian defence forces. Members of the Parliament, the Government in particular and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) above all have a special responsibility to members of the Australian defence forces, because they do not have the opportunities that people in the ordinary work force have to pursue claims for improved conditions of service. They do not have the opportunity to join trade unions which will go on strike or take other forms of industrial action in order to improve their conditions of service. Members of the Australian defence forces must depend on the goodwill of the Government and this Parliament to ensure that they are properly looked after. That is an extraordinarily important point that we as members of the Parliament should remember. We have a great responsibility to our defence forces, and one of the most important of all the roles of government and parliament is to ensure that our country is properly defended.

If the morale of our defence forces is low and if our defence forces themselves are weak, we as members of the Parliament, and the Government in particular, are responsible for that and, more than that, we have a responsibility to improve those conditions of service and the level of morale in our defence forces. We on this side of the House are not ashamed at all in saying that we believe that over the past 4 1/2 years the Government has not pursued that responsibility vigorously or effectively enough. It is all very well towards the end of 1987 to say that there is going to be some sort of inquiry into our defence forces, the conditions of service and why so many personal are resigning. Why was this not done earlier, in 1984, 1985, or 1986? It has gone on and on, the statistics have become worse and worse and the morale of the defence forces has continued to decline. Fancy that happening at a time when the security of our region is becoming increasingly tenuous. It really is very disturbing and I know that members of the Australian community, if not the Government, are deeply worried about it.

Housing, which is the primary theme of this debate in relation to the Australian Defence Force, the ADF, is an important factor. I am glad to say that the one defence facility in my electorate-the Army camp at Woodside-has benefited from a substantial investment in improved housing. I am sure that the Minister will be interested to hear that, although she certainly was not involved in that but her predecessor was. The people at Woodside are an extraordinarily dedicated and committed group of soldiers who are doing a magnificent job under the leadership of Colonel Derbyshire. They deserve the best of facilities and I am very glad that the Government has seen fit to invest in significantly improved housing there over the past two or so years.

People from that camp have raised many issues with me. Certainly, issues have been raised by contractors from the district about the efficiency of the investment and the way the contract has actually been carried out. But at the end of the day, even though the cost may have been significantly more than it might have been if the project had been administered more efficiently, those soldiers are going to have improved conditions of service. I am glad that is going to happen. Of course, housing generally for the defence forces is grossly inadequate. Although the standard of housing is not the only reason people are leaving our defence forces, it is one of the important reasons. Other members have talked already about the flood of resignations from our armed forces. Many have quoted the statistics for 1986-87 when 12.8 per cent of the members of our armed forces resigned. This is a record, with the exception of the period when conscription was brought to an end. We know that 8,900 out of a Defence Force of 70,000 resigned in 1986-87. The previous year, when nothing was done-no inquiry was established and the whole issue was simply neglected-12.3 per cent of our defence forces resigned. It seems to me so sad and such a dereliction of duty that a government should have ignored this problem for so long. We have had over the last five years-the period that this Government has been in office-something like a 50 per cent turnover in personnel in our armed forces.

I want to say a little tonight about the way these resignations have affected the Royal Australia Air Force, an area with which I have had more contact than some other parts of the armed forces. The Air Force has told me on several occasions that housing is a major problem, and I will come back to that later. But there are many other reasons for people leaving the Air Force-in particular, pilots and engineers-than housing alone. One only has to look again at the statistics to see how serious the problem is. Today more pilots are resigning from our Air Force than are being trained. This is a time when our country's level of security, particularly in the Pacific area, is increasingly being jeopardised. We have many foreign policy problems around Australia today. This is not a frivolous party political issue but a serious issue which we as members of parliament ought to address. More pilots are resigning from the Air Force than are being trained. We are losing instructors from the Air Force at a quite extraordinary rate. Recently all of the instructors of 36 Squadron and 37 Squadron, which are based at Richmond and which fly Hercules aircraft, resigned to go to other jobs. Every single one of them resigned. The F18 squadrons recently lost three instructors. There is no question that that is a very serious matter.

Our Orion aircraft form a fundamental part of Australia's coastal surveillance and coastal security function. In saying that, one sets aside the disgraceful Amann Aviation Pty Ltd affair. Look at what is happening with the Orions. The Orion squadrons have lost a large number of engineers. The Edinburgh base, which is the main Orion base in South Australia, had 15 engineers at the beginning of 1986. But 10 of those 15 engineers have by now resigned. Of course, largely they have been replaced. But 10 of the original 15 who were there at the beginning of 1986 have resigned. So this is a chronic problem. It just strikes me, Mr Deputy Speaker-and I would be surprised if you did not agree with me-as quite incredible that nothing has happened in the last 4 1/2 years to address this problem. All we are told today is that an inquiry has been set up, after more than 4 1/2 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I served on the Joint Committee on Public Works for about five years. We went to Townsville, Darwin, Williamtown and elsewhere. That Committee suggested that the wives should be represented at hearings and that they should have the opportunity of saying to us where the laundry should be, or where the kitchen should be, or the cupboards, or the stairways. From the very day the wives came before the Public Works Committee, to my knowledge, we advanced in our recommendations on improving the quality of the homes we should be building for servicemen. Inherent in this legislation is the fact that this new Authority, or whatever the Government is going to call it, will charge rent that will make it pay. In other words, the money that is paid out for the erection, supervision and administration of homes has to be financially self-supporting.

TALK.START.PARA: —None.

—I ask the Minister to give us some figures on this. I can tell her that the servicemen and their families are very concerned that rentals are going up. They are worried about conditions of service such as education, pay and superannuation. When the Minister comes to Williamtown with me, as I hope she will, she and I will be able to talk sensibly to people about these problems, because they are worried about them.

SPEECH.PARA: We as a parliament have a tremendous responsibility. We may line up here to argue and put up stories against each other, but our arguments are designed for only one thing-better legislation for this country. They are designed to bring about sensible, practical legislation that will result in sensible housing with proper rentals for people who are subject to transfer year after year to and from any part of Australia or, if need be, any part of the globe. These are the things that we have to realise. I appeal to the Government to ensure that the efforts that it is making, both within this legislation and elsewhere, will be to the benefit of the servicemen and servicewomen and their families throughout Australia.
