TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to thank honourable members for their contributions to this debate. It is very important in a debate such as this on defence issues, which has become very wide ranging, that we acknowledge the Government's responsibility to take action in the area of defence conditions, but I think we also need to acknowledge the responsibilities of the Opposition. The responsibility of members of the Opposition is to ensure that they are properly informed about defence service conditions and that they do not work to undermine the morale of the Services.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that I am most concerned about in this debate is the fact that the Opposition is deliberately distorting many of the facts-and that is eroding morale. I think it is important that we try to develop a bipartisan approach on these issues, so that together we can work towards a stronger defence force with high morale. I am, however, appreciative of many of the points that have been raised in this debate, and I am particularly appreciative of the support that this legislation has from the Opposition.

I wish to make a few comments on the substance of the points raised by members of the Opposition. Generally, the debate has been conducted along party lines, as to what we have done, what we should have done and what we have not done, but underlying all this is a commitment from this Government to improve service conditions, especially in the area of housing. We have before us tonight a concrete commitment of this Government to our services spouses and members of the defence services. I want to put on record the achievements of this Government in the housing area and compare them with the lack of achievements of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will not take long.

—The honourable member for Casey makes an interjection. I must thank him for his important contribution to this debate. He highlighted the whole crux of this housing problem. He talked about his experience in Snake Creek. I was very sympathetic about his experience in Snake Creek, but I think his experience when he was a Royal Australian Air Force officer over a period of years highlights the housing problems that have existed in this country for a very long time.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first serious attempt by any government to address those problems. After all, when the honourable member's Party was in government it did not give a high priority to spending in the defence housing area, and that has been acknowledged during this by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). In fact, in the five years of this Government's administration, from 1983-84 to 1987-88, capital expenditure on defence housing totalled $259.5m. In the last five years of the previous Government, capital expenditure amounted to a mere $85.2m. In constant prices, this Government's capital outlays over the five-year period is double that of the previous Government over the same period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lies, damned lies and statistics.

—They are not lies; they are simple facts. We have spent $2 to every one of the previous Government's on defence housing. Why have we had to do that? We have had to do it to live up to our commitment to the defence services because when we took over in government the conditions in the defence housing area were so poor. That has been reinforced by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) with his sad story about his life in Snake Creek. As this debate has gone on I have heard many such contributions. For example, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) talked about life in Puckapunyal when he took over as the local member. I had a similar story from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is at the table with me. He told me about his going to see Minister for Defence Killen and telling him about the problems he was having in his electorate. He said, `What sort of response did I get from the then Government? Nil'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Housing Authority Bill is absolutely historic. It is historic in that we are demonstrating our clear commitment to improving conditions in the defence services. I have to admit that we have a long way to go in improving housing and housing maintenance. One of the major things I think we need to do is renegotiate the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In the debate tonight many people have given examples of housing that is of poor standard and desperately in need of repair. One of the major reasons for that, particularly for the repair problem, has been that much of the repairs is done by the State governments. I am committed to renegotiating that agreement, because I want the very best deal possible for members of our defence services. I am sick of their living in areas which are considered purely welfare areas, and I want to see a major improvement in repairs.

I was asked by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) what the Government's priorities are. I think repairs are a major priority. I think it is essential that we make maximum use of local contracts. I have already had representatives of the interim defence housing board come to see me, and I have told them that that is my priority, principally because it is very difficult to see any immediate impact from the establishment of this Authority in the building of houses. They take time to appear, but I think we should have some quick results in the area of repairs and maintenance, particularly with the use of local contractors.

One of the possibilities that I would like to explore further is that of having some self-help projects, particularly on our larger bases. I think that, if the Authority supplied some of the equipment, some of the minor work could possibly be done by the defence service personnel and their families. Many of them get sick of waiting to have minor repairs done when, if we could give some assistance to them, they might be able to deal with it themselves. I do not want to abrogate our responsibility in this area, but I think together we can work to overcome this problem.

Another matter raised with me was the issue of home ownership. This is an area about which I am very enthusiastic. There are all sorts of ways in which we can look at developing a home ownership scheme, and these are matters which I am examining now. The real housing disabilities of service families arise from their requirement to relocate frequently, and it is therefore essential that they have appropriate rental accommodation, but I think it is also important, particularly in today's modern age, to recognise that people, whether they are defence service personnel or not, want to own their own homes. One of the key things that I would like to achieve is greater home ownership amongst our defence service personnel. That is one of the positive aspects of providing a cash grant under the defence home loans scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —An adequate cash grant?
—An adequate cash grant is one thing.
—You are talking a riot; you are talking nonsense.

—An adequate cash grant is one thing. Basically, I do not think that we should totally dismiss the cash grant out of hand. I think that for many of our Defence Service families it may be an advantage to have a cash grant, rather than the long term loan. I think that it is essential that we have a very serious look at that, as we are doing in the course of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point to which I want to refer concerns barracks accommodation. As honourable members will be aware, this legislation really does not deal with the issue of barracks accommodation. However, it is an important issue. I think that one of the key things which a government-and an opposition-needs to do all the time is to look at its priorities. Basically, I see our major priority as appropriately housing our families. That is the point of this legislation. However, it is still very important that we do not neglect our single personnel. Many of these personnel live off base because they say the barracks lack privacy. Barracks accommodation is special purpose and is located on base, whereas the housing required for the Australian Defence Force (ADF) is no different from community needs generally. So at this stage the Defence Housing Authority is dealing with housing for families. Undoubtedly, over time, the Authority will be able to contribute to meeting the ADF's requirement for barracks. That may be a natural progression of its activities. In the first instance, however, I think it is important that we get it to concentrate on the housing task; recognising the extent of the problem that has to be faced.

The Government is addressing the problem of barracks accommodation. In the last four years over $50m has been spent on this. Besides Tindal, other bases, that have had significant amounts spent on barracks are the Army base at Enoggera and the Royal Australian Air Force bases at East Sale and Williamtown. I noticed also when I was in Townsville that quite an amount was being spent at the base there. On present planning another $240m will be spent on barracks during the next five-year period. I think it is important that we still give some emphasis to the concerns of the single person.

Many other issues have been canvassed in this debate. It has been a pretty free-ranging debate which has dealt with issues such as separation problems, the recommendations of the Hamilton Review of the Effect of Service Life on Spouses and on service conditions in general. I do not want to delve into these issues now as the hour is late and we have had considerable debate on them in the Parliament today-debate which I welcome. However I want to say in relation to the issue of separation that there is no doubt that we have a problem and we are looking at specific areas, for example, the separation of pilots, which has been raised by a couple of honourable members tonight. We are addressing those problems. There is no way that the Government will ignore them.

Rather than throwing our hands up in despair we are targeting the areas we see as being of concern. We are looking at ways of addressing that problem, both in terms of working conditions and career opportunities and also in terms of what we can negotiate with potential employers such as Qantas Airways Ltd. We do not want to limit opportunities for people who want to leave the Services. We have a voluntary service. On the other hand, we have a responsibility to ensure that we get the best value from the people we train. Therefore, it is important that we keep as many people in the Services for as long as we can, particularly those who have cost a great deal of money to train.

I am addressing many of the details of the implementation of the Hamilton report. One important initiative that has not been given enough attention relates to the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff which is being established throughout Australia. It involves a network of contacts to assist defence personnel in any problems that arise for them in adjusting to new bases. It is assisting defence families in adjusting to their lives in the defence services.

I would also like to make a comment at this time about my consultant, Mrs Mayer, who has been much maligned in this debate tonight. First of all, a few facts need to be stated here. Mrs Mayer is receiving the salary of a Level 1 officer. I have no idea where the figure of half a million dollars that the Opposition is raising all the time comes from.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are asking how many staff are in the office, and so on.

—I have actually answered these questions before. I find that the Opposition never seems to listen to the answers. As an opposition it has a responsibility not to distort the facts. Mrs Mayer has been appointed by me as a consultant--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mrs KELLY

TALK.START.PARA: —What we need to do is to implement such recommendations. I know quite clearly what needs to be achieved for our defence service personnel in these matters. We also have clear discrepancies with car registrations as we cross State boundaries.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mrs KELLY

TALK.START.PARA: —These are matters that have to be clearly negotiated with State governments. I think that these are issues of great concern to our Defence Force personnel. INTERJECT.PARA: I will go back to the substance of this debate about the housing issue. I appreciated the comments raised by several honourable members about the role of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses. I also am very enthusiastic about having the Group's advice on defence housing issues. Honourable members who are interested in the details of this legislation will know that clause 24 (9) of the Bill provides for the Authority to ask people to attend meetings. I am going to request the Authority to invite the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses to send a spouse to attend the meetings. My view is that in the longer term we will have that Group formally represented on the Authority when we bring in future amendments to the legislation.

The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) raised the subject of quangos and the need for these authorities to stick to their tasks. I could not agree with him more. I have always been an opponent of the formation of statutory authorities. However, I think in this instance we have a need for a statutory authority with some flexibility. All honourable members who have contributed to the debate have talked about the restrictions in providing defence housing. It has always been done according to certain specifications. I have heard the most bizarre stories about people who were not entitled, for example, to a house with an ensuite and so the ensuite was ripped out. These are the bizarre sorts of things that apply as a result of rules and regulations. One of the advantages of the Authority is its flexibility. I hope that the Authority will address issues such as the one raised by the honourable member for McEwen that related to the colour of the walls. I cannot see any reason in the world why one should have to have 11 pairs of curtains if one has 11 postings. Surely there are some standards by which we can abide so we do not have to go through this nonsense. These are the advantages of an independent authority.

I give this House a guarantee that I will be watching the work of the Authority like a hawk. The Authority has as its charter the need to provide defence housing for our service personnel. I have asked it to give emphasis to repairs of defence housing. I will ensure that it does that. If it does not, I will be back here to tell honourable members why it does not. If it does not, I will abolish it. That is the commitment I give this House.

Before I conclude this debate, I would like to make particular reference to the issue of rents. I do not want a debate starting in the community that the establishment of this Authority means that there will be an increase in rents. That is not the case. I want to make it very clear that we do have a system of subsidised rents for defence service personnel and that that will continue. The way this Authority will work is that it will charge commercial rents to the Department of Defence, but the Department of Defence will then subsidise the homes of the defence service personnel. This legislation does not mean that there will be an end to subsidised rentals. The Government agrees that Australian Defence Force rents should be at subsidised levels. This Government has been the first to adopt a set of principles on the provision of housing for its employees among which is a recognition of the need to compensate personnel for housing related disabilities arising from frequent relocation. That is an important commitment of this Government. As I said, I do not want any furphies circulating around our defence forces that it is anything but that.

Finally, I conclude by thanking all the members for their contributions-the honourable member for McPherson, the honourable member for Farrer, the honourable member for Hughes, the honourable member for Casey, the honourable member for Hunter, the honourable member for Herbert, the honourable member for Mayo and the honourable member for McEwen. It is setting up a new authority. It will give priority to repairs and it is very committed to the improvement of the defence services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent years I have had occasion to complain about developments with the administration of tax law and particularly as it applied to pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers. My concern has stemmed mainly from increases in discretionary power which has been conferred by successive Acts of Parliament and amendments on the Commissioner of Taxation. In recent times my objections and concerns have been heightened; in particular, I refer to developments in Perth involving certain members-I emphasise the words `certain members'-of the Australian Taxation Office in Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening is tantamount to horse trading by public servants in a way which this Parliament certainly never intended when it passed the relevant laws which enable that sort of behaviour to take place. It has become worse than that in Perth in recent times. I have no hesitation in using the adjectives `intimidation' and even `extortion' when referring to the techniques employed by some officers of the Australian Taxation Office in Perth. Worse than that, although there is no evidence that there has been corruption in the sense that individuals in the Taxation Office may gain something personally, there is a great potential for corruption under the Act as it stands now and particularly in the way it is approached by these certain people to whom I have referred.

It has already been noticed in the Press that the Australian Taxation Office, like any branch of the civil service, is not immune from corruption of one sort or another. In fact, we have seen recent reports of there being some sort of a drug distribution network in the Australian Taxation Office in Perth. I only mention that to indicate that the possibilities for malpractice of all sorts exist. There are allegations, there has been one reported arrest and I understand that the Australian Federal Police is pursuing investigations in respect of certain other officers.

The most blatant and very serious breach, and the only one in my time in this Parliament that I have heard of, is a reported breach, an alleged breach, of the section 16 secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act by a particular officer whom I shall not name because it is not important for me to do so here tonight. It involved the disclosure to an unrelated third party of the details of an investigation into a pay as you earn taxpayer. That taxpayer is Ms Alison Fan. I will not go into the circumstances that led up to the particular instance I want to mention here tonight although, in themselves, they give cause for great complaint.

The fact is that an officer of the Taxation Office, in discussions with an unrelated third party who happens to be a tax accountant, but nothing to do with Ms Fan's affairs, disclosed the details of the original assessment and what eventually happened because she had the gall to resist and to question the investigators involved in that particular exercise. There were other doubtful and perhaps illegal practices included in the same conversation by the same gentleman to the same unrelated third party involving the impersonation of medical practitioners to obtain information from Medicare. But I shall not go into that.

The clear objective of this gentleman was to persuade this unrelated third party, the accountant acting on behalf of a couple of clients, that resistance to their assessments and their opinions was pointless. If that resistance took place, they could expect the same treatment, the same doubtful treatment, handed out to my constituent, Ms Fan.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with grave concern that I view the Government's intention to establish a casino on Christmas Island. But, as Julianne Schultz says, both the steel division profit and the 15,000 people who no longer worked for BHP were the enduring testament to this wonderful exercise in restructuring. Of those 15,000 people, 8,000 lived in the Wollongong area. Today many of them are still out of work, as are many other people who subsequently lost their jobs through the multiplier effect.

Things were not always this way with the Big Australian. Back in the late fifties, and into the sixties and seventies, BHP went from strength to strength. Productivity increased with improved steel-making capacity and profits went up and up, enhanced as they were by a vigorous export trade. And underlying this wonderful expansion were the blood, sweat and toil of its coal miners and steel-workers. Back in the 1960s, BHP had little difficulty in financing its costly developments. As its profits went up, thanks largely to its steel-making, BHP was able to attract the necessary capital to finance its expansion into other areas of industry, notably gas and oil production and the export of coal, iron ore and other minerals. But make no mistake about this. The basis of this highly profitable expansion was always the profits made in BHP's steel-working division-and the basis of those profits were the men and women who worked in its steel mills and coal mines. Today, BHP says it must lift its steel-making productivity to higher levels. I do not contest this. Nor do I contest the need for greater efficiency.

What does cause me grave concern, however, is that BHP now says it must shed another 2,600 jobs at its Port Kembla steel-works as part of this new phase of restructuring. It is estimated that the loss of 2,600 jobs at the Port Kembla steelworks could mean the overall loss of some 7,500 jobs in the Illawarra area. BHP Port Kembla says that its original intention was to lift productivity by spending $183m to rebuild its No. 4 blast furnace, which would markedly increase iron and steel production. Now it says it cannot raise the finance to do so. Since BHP cannot lift its productivity by increasing its output, the only alternative is to reduce its work force.

The question is: Just as BHP once used its steel-making profits to develop into other highly profitable areas of industrial activity, why cannot the Big Australian now turn around and use its profits from these newer areas of activity to finance the updating of its iron and steel-making at Port Kembla? BHP's answer is that there has been a policy change. Once it had a policy of cross-subsidisation of its various areas of activity; now it has a policy of no cross-subsidisation. And the people who will suffer from this new policy are the very people who, by their toil, helped BHP become what it is today. BHP says it can shed the jobs at Port Kembla by the end of 1988 through a process of natural attrition and the voluntary retirement scheme. The steelworking unions question whether this can be done-and so do I.

This much I do know: the steel plan expires at the end of next year. Under the steel plan, the company agreed there would be no further retrenchments during the life of the plan. But once the plan expires at the end of 1988, BHP will not be so bound-and it has recently announced that it does not intend to embark on a renewed steel plan. It is the old story of the free enterprise system: the more capital one has, the freer one is to enter into enterprises which influence one's productivity and one's profit making ability-and if in the process one must consign to oblivion one's workers and their families, that is just too bad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members would know, Australian merino breeders are restricted to a quota of 500 rams per year that can be sent overseas. Though I do not agree with that restriction, I want to speak of the requirement which states that whatever of these rams are sold to overseas interests should be sold not only though the auction system but at designated auctions. The reasons we are given for this are: firstly, so the authorities can keep tabs on the number sold and regulate anything pertaining to these sales, as authorities like to do; and, secondly, so that any Australian buyer will have a chance to bid on any ram that is eligible for overseas sale. That may sound reasonable but only about 0.1 per cent of total rams sold in Australia go overseas. In other words, 99.9 per cent are sold to local, domestic buyers. Therefore, the overall effect on prices from the sale of rams for overseas should be negligible.

SPEECH.PARA: However, because this overseas buying is concentrated in only a few designated sales this can have a distorting effect on the market. It can force up the price of rams at these sales, which is a visible effect. Though this is good for stud breeders, it raises the ire of commercial buyers and stirs up the emotions of many associated with the wool industry. For these reasons, I believe the designated sales requirement should be done away with. It should at least be greatly modified, especially where it has wasteful consequences. A classic example of this occurred recently in my electorate of Parkes. It took place at last week's Dubbo Merino Sheep Show, which is the largest of its type in the world.

At this show were some 70 merino rams from the Lewisdale merino stud of East Wickepin in Western Australia. They were tall, rangy, long-bodied, plain sheep with open horns and a very hardy constitution. Their wool fibre diameter ranged from 23 to 27 micron, with some kemp fibres protruding from the body of the fleece. These rams had in fact already been `purchased' by Algerian buyers at Lewisdale quite some time ago. They were just what the Algerians were looking for: hardy sheep with meat characteristics that would survive in the harshness of the Algerian climate. They were in fact similar to the type of sheep that China is looking for, only that country is somewhat more fussy about the wool characteristics. In short, the sheep were ideal for overseas buyers but not particularly sought after by the buyers at the Dubbo Sheep Show. Consequently, when they came up for auction all were `sold' to Algeria. Not one Australian bought one of those rams, which averaged, I believe, $731, for a gross price of just over $50,000.

Why were these Western Australian sheep being sold at Dubbo in New South Wales? It was because Dubbo was the only available designed auction sale remaining this year and, because of deadlines, if those sheep were not sold and loaded within two days of the auction the whole sale would have fallen through. In fact, there were only four designated auctions across Australia, each starting with a quota of 125 rams that could be sold overseas. So as soon as those 70 rams were `sold' they immediately had to be loaded on to a truck and taken as fast as possible back across the continent to Western Australia to Fremantle where they had to be loaded on a ship there destined to sail within 48 hours to the Middle East.

I am delighted to announce that because of the driving skills of the truck driver those rams just made it in time. However, Mr Ray Lewis, the owner, whom I spoke to at Dubbo, told me of the costs involved. There was $4,000 freight each way; air fares to and from Western Australia for Mr Lewis and the three or four people who accompanied him; accommodation, wages and other incidentals for these people; and $30 a ram pen fee in Dubbo plus feed and so on-a total of $14,000 to $15,000 completely down the tubes. That is, almost 30 per cent of the gross for those rams at the sale was totally wasted.

The whole manner in which rams for export are sold needs total revision. Personally, I believe the designated auction system should be scrapped. However, at the very least we must have some changes. For example, there is no reason why those rams that were auctioned could not have been sold by video. That would have saved over $2,000 in pen fees alone, let alone the $8,000 in freight costs and so on. Obviously a better system has to be worked out whereby the rams can be inspected on the farms beforehand and perhaps go through the health protocol tests there before being offered for sale. The potential for overseas sales of even the types of rams that Australian wool growers do not want is quite substantial. Those involved should get together to devise the best system that will benefit everyone and cut out this nonsensical sort of consequence I have just spoken about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), in the chamber tonight because I wish to make a few comments on the welcome home parade for Vietnam veterans which was organised for 3 October in Sydney. The welcome home parade was a great success. The point I wish to take issue with is some comments made on that welcome home parade by Senator Jo Vallentine. The comments made tonight by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) have not triggered my adjournment speech but I think a few things have to be said. I wish to quote from a Press report which was run on Monday 5 October under the headline `Parade ``an insult'' '. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Today's welcome-home parade in Sydney for Vietnam veterans only adds insult to their sufferings, West Australian Senator Jo Vallentine, said yesterday.
``Instead of a parade, these people deserve an apology for being sent to fight America's war,'' she said.
Senator Vallentine said there was no doubt the veterans and their families had suffered greatly and deserved full support and compassion.
``But we must not lose sight of the fact that they were not serving Australia's interests in Vietnam,'' she said.
``They were serving the overseas interests of the United States.
``Tomorrow's welcome-home parade, 15 years after the soldiers were brought home, only adds insult to what they have already suffered.''

Madam Speaker, I believe that a very large number of Vietnam veterans would consider those comments made by Senator Vallentine grossly insulting. The Vietnam veterans simply obeyed the law of the land which was established by the Government which was elected at that time by the Australian people. Many Vietnam veterans suffered great physical and psychological damage as a result of their service in Vietnam. I know that there are many honourable members in this House, including the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, who have fought over many years to protect the rights of veterans, including some who perhaps have suffered as a result of the spraying of agent orange and other defoliants in Vietnam.

Madam Speaker, I think comments made by other people who marched in the parade perhaps better express the views of Australians. In the Sydney Morning Herald, Mr John Mathew, who was one of the Vietnam veterans who marched on that day, made the following comments:
When we marched down those streets yesterday we really knew we had come home at last. We could feel the bitterness, the hate and the misunderstanding washing away with every step we took.

The fact that the many tens of thousands of Australians from Sydney and other places who attended that welcome home parade stood and applauded for I think more than 90 minutes as the parade marched past said a great deal for the affection which those who turned out had for the veterans who had returned home. I quote another comment from the march's chief organiser, Mr Peter Poulton:
After the march, fellows kept coming up to me and saying, `This is the greatest thing that ever happened'. They said it felt like they had just come home-that it was the end of the war.'

Mr Poulton went on to say that there were plans for the establishment of a national memorial in Canberra for those who served in Vietnam and that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had made some encouraging comments.

Tonight I simply place on record my support for the establishment of a commemorative memorial in Canberra for those who served in Vietnam. In my own local area, the Central Coast and Hunter Valley Vietnam Veterans Association was closely associated with the welcome home parade in Sydney. Organisers and members of the Central Coast and Hunter Valley Vietnam Veterans Association, such as Gordon Reed, Ken Bott and Ted Eaves, put a lot of work into organising and transporting Central Coast and Hunter Valley veterans to that march in Sydney. At the moment, they are seeking to encourage community support for the establishment of a hostel for Vietnam veterans and their dependants on the central coast. I hope that that receives sympathetic consideration from the Government in the coming months.

Once again, I condemn Senator Jo Vallentine's comments. I think she was seeking to score a few cheap political points from a march organised by people of all shades of political opinion and sympathy who wanted to give Vietnam veterans who suffered psychological and physical damage a great experience. I think the march was greatly appreciated by all Vietnam veterans who were able to get to Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening, during debate on the Defence Housing Authority Bill, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) posed a question which I would like to take this opportunity to answer. He referred to my recollections of the rigours of service life at the Royal Australian Air Force base at Snake Creek and correctly pointed out that at the time my family and I were posted there a Liberal government was directing the destiny of this nation. He also quite correctly said that the appalling housing conditions to which I alluded during my speech were a result of the policies of the then Liberal Government. Why, he asked, would anybody who had supposedly suffered at the hands of the Liberals want to join them, let alone represent them in this Parliament?

SPEECH.PARA: The answer is very simple, and it is summed up very adequately in the words used by the late Sir Robert Menzies, in his opening address to the conference which he convened in Canberra in October 1944-some 43 years ago, give or take a week or two-and which resulted in the formation of the Liberal Party of Australia. At that time the then Mr Menzies said:

What we must look for, and it is a matter of desperate importance to our country, is a true revival of liberal thought, which will work for social justice and security, for national power and national progress, and for the full development of the individual citizen . . . though not through the dull and deadening process of socialism.

I believe he was right. And because I believed in the sentiments he expressed in that speech-sentiments which are embodied in the policies and philosophies of the Liberal Party, I joined that Party-that is why I represent the Liberal Party in this Parliament today. I must admit that I did consider the alternatives. I considered them carefully, and I rejected them totally. And as I contemplate the so-called program of reforms initiated by this Labor Government-reforms which it claims are aimed at building a fairer and more compassionate Australian society and which entail, in Labor's words, `The continued acceptance by the whole community of the need for hard decisions which will be necessary to overcome the basic problems facing this nation'-I wonder just how sincere the Labor Party actually is. On the one hand, this Government speaks of a fairer and more compassionate society; whilst, on the other, it vigorously pursues policies which, by any definition, are discriminatory both in theory and in practice.

There is really no need for the whole community to steel itself to accept the hard decisions, because in fact the whole community is not usually involved; it is the middle-class, middle-income earners, veterans, senior citizens, small business people and those on fixed incomes who are the most popular and, in many cases, the most vulnerable `hard decision' targets. Our present socialist ship of state and all who sail in her, including the honourable member for McEwen, are well and truly headed for the rocks-very likely those on the Argentinean coastline. As they contemplate the social, moral and economic wreck that is the result of their ill-founded endeavours, perhaps they will have time to recall these words of Adlai Stevenson:
More important than winning elections is governing the nation. That is the test of a political party-the acid, final test.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a ridiculous statement! We have just been re-elected.

—That is the acid and final test, and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs should take cognisance of that. Perhaps it is taking longer than most of us expected-and certainly longer than this country can afford-but it is a test that this Government will eventually fail. Unfortunately, the honourable member for McEwen will lose his seat at the next election; otherwise, I would have been delighted to have debated the issue with him further when I serve my third term and my first term as a member of the next Liberal government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not risen this evening to speak on the Liberal Party in the brief time available to me-that is just a waste of time. I saw the faces of the veterans-the men and women-who took part, and they certainly were pleased to be able to receive a long overdue welcome. However, I must admit that during the Vietnam war I protested against the then Government. I was one of the radicals who marched up and down Bourke Street at the time and actually laid down in Bourke Street and was threatened with arrest. At the time I worked for a firm known as Spicer's Business Machines-it is no longer in business so I can say this, and the manager will not get the sack-and the manager threatened me with the sack if I attended that march. TALK.START.PARA: —It was not the veterans' fault.

—The veterans had nothing to do with it. They were obeying orders, doing what they were told at the time was correct. It was the fault of the Government at the time. At the time I was not a member of any political party and, in fact, I did not join until eight or nine years ago. But that must have influenced my thinking-the wrong decisions made by a conservative government. It was wrong to send our people to Vietnam to fight in a phoney war.

SPEECH.PARA: However, as I said, it was pleasing to go to Sydney about a month ago and see these men and women march. They were pleased and there was a lot of very proud faces. I can assure the people who took part in the march that I was proud to be there to see them return home and receive the welcome that was due and fitting for the amount of effort that they put into protecting the cherished ideals of this nation, although those ideals were falsified by the Government of the day. What the then conservative Government did at that time was wrong-it will always be wrong and I will always remember that. That is one reason why I will stand and do my utmost to prevent a government of that type being elected to this Parliament again.
